Telecoms regulator Oftel has issued "tough" guidelines on the roll-out of broadband internet access in the UK, amid mounting criticism that BT is holding up the process.

BT said it is seeking clarification on the guidelines, particularly the demand that its exchanges be made available within four months. A spokesperson said this should apply only to four trial exchanges, which will be ready by January.

The news represents the latest bout of uncertainty in a process that this week saw Oftel bow to pressure from telecoms operators and select 360 BT exchanges for the installation of broadband equipment. Thirty-five companies are bidding for access to local exchanges.

The regulator also moved to end the squabbling between operators and BT, saying it will resolve all disputes over price and space allocation.

David Edmonds, director general of Oftel, said: "Local loop unbundling will bring a step change to businesses, consumers and the telecoms industry itself. I am determined to implement it as quickly as possible so that all companies can compete fairly to deliver these revolutionary new high-speed services."

Edmonds has gone back to the drawing board after admitting earlier this week that Oftel should have been firmer in its handling of the process and submitted proposals sooner.

The announcement comes as operators' complaints over BT's behaviour reach a crescendo, with RSL Communications and Global Crossing withdrawing from the bidding process and Colt Telecom demanding a quicker roll out.

US telecoms group WorldCom yesterday also stepped away, citing "commercial and business reasons", while denying any frustration with BT.

RSL said the broadband internet market was wide open for BT, because initial access for rival operators is restricted to local exchanges. BT said it would take longer to open up urban exchanges, where competitors will be fighting for space.

"The regulators should be more hands-on," said one analyst. "Evidence in the US shows that strong regulation is needed for this kind of thing. There needs to be more intervention from Oftel to chivvy BT along, although I understand it is a very complicated process."

The "loop" being unbundled is the last mile of copper wires connecting homes to the network, which is then made available for broadband internet operators. Oftel said there will be full competition by 2001, but observers have poured scorn on the pace of the roll-out.

Serafino Abape, of telecoms consultancy Ovum, said: "European countries are completely inexperienced in dealing with unbundling, and there is no pan-European legislation offering a firm guide."

BT's shares tumbled 5.7% to 746p, following a profits warning on Wednesday from Sprint Corporation of the US.

Every so often a no-budget independent film sneaks out that is so fresh, it makes everything else at the cinema look old hat. Swingers, a sharply observed twist on the romantic comedy that Jon Favreau wrote when his career as an actor was stuttering, was one of those films. Its release in 1996 spawned catchphrases ("You're so money!"), a revival of lounge clubs in Canada, and countless homages as twentysomethings were inspired to tell their own tale.

Among the many such scripts Favreau has received in the past five years was Valerie Breiman's Love and Sex, a study of one woman's contorted relationship history that so caught his attention that he agreed to star in it, opposite Famke Janssen. He soon discovered just how autobiographical Breiman's script was: while directing, she developed a habit of rushing on set and telling her actors: "No, it happened more like this."

Breiman's film lacks the verbal and visual inventiveness that made Swingers such a delight, but this never impinges on Favreau's performance: he inhabits his character, Adam, like it's his favourite pair of pyjamas. Favreau has nothing but admiration for Breiman: "I don't think anyone is getting the new independent voice particularly right," he says, with the authority of one who is certain he has, "and it's rare that you come across a strong, personal, well-written film like Love and Sex."

He sounds like Breiman's agent, but genuine too - a quality that emerges repeatedly. When he describes his co-starring role in Love and Sex as "a really good second fiddle", he radiates an unassuming geniality that you wouldn't expect from a Hollywood player. On film, his old-fashioned niceness recalls romantic heroes of the black-and-white era: watching him bantering with Janssen, he makes you think of James Stewart and Margaret Sullavan in The Shop Around the Corner. His characters aren't perfect - "I don't mind playing guys who look foolish," he says - but they are essentially good, something that is important to him.

"I would never want to do a rape scene, for example," he says. "It's hard to weigh in on the subject because of the movement towards censorship, but there's a moral imperative in film-making to realise that some people are looking to the screen to learn their lessons. I certainly did."

He was born in New York in 1966, and although his grandmother, father and - before her death when Favreau was 12 - his mother were all teachers, he dropped out of university. He moved to Chicago, and eight years passed in a frustrating haze of adverts and minor parts. Favreau is grateful that fame was elusive: "Prince William," he says, "is 18, he's on the cover of magazines, and he hasn't done anything. I feel sorry for him. At 30 I was in a movie that brought me a lot of attention, I'm getting to do what I want to do and this is the price I pay for it. And then, I'm in a relationship with a woman I probably wouldn't have met if it hadn't been for Swingers, because that was how she approached me: to discuss that film." Doesn't he feel like he's stepped aside from real life? "Yeah," he grins, "but I never liked the other life that much anyway."

Favreau's career reads like a boy's fantasy. He was Courteney Cox's millionaire boyfriend in Friends and Cameron Diaz's fiance in Very Bad Things. He's been an astronaut (Deep Impact), a football player (The Replacements, yet to be released here), even Rocky Marciano in a made-for-TV biopic. "Boys get into acting because they want to meet girls," Favreau smiles, "but it's also to be like a little kid playing cowboys and indians."

At the moment Favreau is editing Made, about two boxers from LA getting swallowed up in New York's crime underbelly, which he has written, produced, starred in and directed. This behind-the-scenes control allows him to help other wannabe actors to break into cinema. On Made, that hopeful is none other than Sean "Puffy" Combs.

Favreau's praise of the buffoonish rapper is unsurprisingly effusive, and it's hard not to laugh when he innocently describes Puffy as "a man who brings a lot of life experience to what he's doing", including his role in Made as a New York crime don. Puffy's involvement did mean that New York's clubs were delighted to accommodate Favreau's cameras; on the downside, his time with Puffy proved to him that his Swingers-style party days are numbered. "It was interesting to get a taste of it," he says, "but I couldn't hang out with him every night. I can't keep up with him that well."

With their stunning bad taste and cheerfully offensive excursions into racial and sexual comedy, the Farrelly brothers have given much amusement, and in the process become Hollywood's licensed jesters in their own carefully delineated field of non-PC entertainment. Me, Myself & Irene, starring Jim Carrey, is their new venture. Broader than broad, it is written, produced and directed by Peter and Bobby, with credits for Mike Cerrone and Bradley Thomas on script and production.

And they give us everything we hope and expect of them - plus a bit more. Frantic masturbation scene involving a sweet young woman? Check. Pointlessly violent assault on a defenceless animal? Check. Jokes involving racial and minority groups? Check. But there's one group in particular to be offended - retards! (I am quoting the exquisitely provocative formulation used by Matt Dillon in There's Something About Mary.) Peter and Bobby raise the issue of those who are, as they say, mentally challenged and appear to add a raucous challenge of their own.

The brothers get away with most of these flourishes on account of their sheer insouciant conviction and comic brio, plus the unspoken understanding that the jibes are a slap at white liberal condescension. But it isn't obvious that the gags about crazy people quite come off - of which more in a moment.

Jim Carrey gives us his usual body-popping, face-squeezing, crowd-pleasing masterclass in physical comedy. With his open, innocent expression, buzz cut and air of perpetual perplexity, he looks like no one so much as Dick York in the 60s TV show Bewitched.

He plays Charlie Baileygates, an all-American white-bread regular guy and Rhode Island state trooper whose life is shattered when his bride falls in love with the, ahem, vertically challenged African-American limo driver who ferries them home from the church. She runs off, leaving Charlie with three black triplets, and Charlie is in denial about his feelings, until they boil over 15 years later in the form of a bizarre split personality. Or, as this film insists on putting it, schizophrenia. Thereafter Charlie's Jekyll and Hyde personalities both fall in love with a young woman called Irene (Renée Zellweger), who is on the run from corrupt federal officials led by the sinister Lt Gerke (a reliably excellent Chris Cooper).

There is a scene at the very beginning of this film in which the Farrellys' horrible genius is deployed to its fullest. On his wedding day, poor, inoffensive Charlie inadvertently offends his small black driver, who erupts with rage and ends up attacking him with what look like martial-arts nunchakas. Naturally, only a real nincompoop could object to this scene; in its sheer excessive outrageousness, it is brilliant, but it also functions unmistakably as a little pre-emptive strike at any uptight bores who are thinking of whining about offensiveness. Here is a funny black midget, it is saying, and here is a joke about someone accidentally offending him. OK?

Then there is the uproarious scene in which Charlie and Irene find a dead cow in the road; trying to carry it out of the way, Charlie discovers it is actually still alive but in agony. So he tries to kill it, first by emptying his pistol into its head and then by strangling it, while the persistent beast moos merrily away. It's inspired in its own delirious way, and let down only by the fact that it is obviously some sort of animatronic cow.

The inevitable self-pleasuring scene comes when Irene enters Charlie's hotel room, dismayed to find him with an official police photo of her, surrounded by sticky crumpled tissues and an absurdly large dispenser of hand-cream. This hardly has the inventiveness of the legendary Cameron-Diaz-hair-gel sequence from There's Something About Mary, which was actually a comment of tactless inspiration on the way modern media encourage male consumers literally and figuratively to jerk off over female images like the miraculously beautiful Diaz. But it does have that bull-in-a-china-shop aptness, an acknowledgement of the open secret of adult male masturbation rarely found in any other film of any genre.

But now we come back to the "schizophrenia" issue, which has had mental health charities up in arms. The split-personality device gives Carrey an opportunity for his usual bravura dual-character playing, in the tradition of the Nutty Professors of Jerry Lewis and Eddie Murphy, and Steve Martin in All of Me. His condition is repeatedly described as "advanced involuntary schizophrenia". Do the Farrelly boys realise that "schizophrenia" is an ignorant solecism here? Worryingly, the answer isn't clear.

The classic definition of a gentleman is someone who never gives offence accidentally. Something similar applies to the Farrellys' brand of non-PC mischief if it is to be successful. But here it looks oddly as if the brothers have simply blundered. Here their sophistication, and their attack radar for mealy-mouthed liberal sensibilities, have gone a bit wrong.

The gag rate of Me, Myself & Irene falls off exponentially in the last half of the picture, and there's a bit of straining to make the plot ends tie up. There's a lot of crazy energy and debonair disregard for the rules of liberal good taste; but when the laughs fall away and the comedy-nous falters, these things get very wearing indeed.

The director of Get Carter, one of the hardest, seediest, most brutal depictions of poverty-backdropped criminal life ever committed to celluloid, lives in a lovely cottage deep in rural Dorset. It is hidden away down a rough dirt track, and is surrounded by a large garden with hammocks and apple trees. "I'm a small man, and quite a gentle one," says Mike Hodges, whose most recent film, Croupier, has become an unexpected US success, two years after FilmFour made it clear that they weren't going to help their own product find a distributor in Britain. "I don't think I've ever punched anyone in my life. But after the success of Carter, women treated me differently. I had criminals come up to me and say, 'Well done for telling it like it is.' I wanted to hang my head and hide."

Hodges' career has been coloured by a discernible lack of pattern. Having started off on World in Action documentaries, he is best known for two films at the opposite end of the spectrum: the violent reality of Get Carter, the story of a bitter man seeking revenge against villains; and the camp fantasy of Flash Gordon, telling the story of a hunk battling Ming the Merciless. He has also made the sci-fi drama The Terminal Man, Pulp, starring Caine again, and the comedy Morons From Outer Space.

"People should come out at the end of a film not being conscious of the director," says Hodges. "Obviously someone like Hitchcock has an immediately recognisable style, but I've always felt that the pot pourri of the film-making process should dictate how the film should be; that the film itself will tell the director what is needed."

So what kind of films would be in the video collection of a director with such an eclectic style? Documentaries figure heavily. "In the mid-90s there were three excellent ones from America, the first of which was Crumb [Terry Zwigoff's film about cartoonist Robert Crumb's family]. It was so detailed, such an incredible portrayal of the couch grass of emotions between this extraordinary family, it makes most other documentaries seem terribly superficial. Then there's Hoop Dreams, again shot over a long period of time so that the film-makers became part of the woodwork and everything was allowed to emerge naturally; and When We Were Kings. I was working in the States in the 70s when TV was in control of the networks, and the only time you would see anything political was on the Sunday morning documentaries. I suppose those three came out of that tradition. And I keep a lot of documentaries here because they always prove useful as source material."

Hodges does not use these classics for borrowing, though. "All this cross-referencing I find a little embarrassing. For Carter, I drew on my experiences in the navy, where I met a really seamy side of British society. The ports we went to were poverty-stricken, and when I shot Carter 15 years later, I went back to North Shields. It was perfect for a hard visualisation of what Jack was like. It had to be a ruthless, uncompromising film and you couldn't romanticise the world it was portraying."

A little different from the world of Flash Gordon, then. "That was based on a comic strip so it had to be like a strip cartoon, and he's the perfect American hero, very dumb indeed. But I was making it with Dino de Laurentiis and an Italian set designer who was completely out of control. He created a set for Arborea, with trees the circumference of this room, and he would say, 'Eesn't eet fantasteec?' And I would say, 'But where am I supposed to put the camera?' He didn't look at the script once."

Other films in the Dorset living room include Truffaut, early Godard, Billy Wilder and John Huston. "And there's no one to replace the great film-makers like Bergman, Kurosawa and Fellini. I did the English version of a Fellini film called The Ship Sails On, and had to go out to Rome to meet him. A born director. We sat down at a restaurant for lunch, about 10 of us, and he'd say, 'No no, this table isn't in the right direction.' So we'd all get up and move it, then he'd change his mind and we'd move it again. He was a charming reprobate, and absolutely hopeless when it came to telling the truth."

Hodges admits to being out of touch with modern directors. "Spielberg and Lucas have done enormous damage to the film art. The music tells you how to emote and feel, it's a button being pushed, it's Pavlovian. I like some of the Coen brothers films, and Scorsese I really admire. Woody Allen's are wonderfully made but rather too smart for me. I didn't like American Beauty. There's a very good film called Happiness which made American Beauty look ludicrous."

Hodges was prepared to give up film-making after FilmFour boss David Aukin told him that the only thing he liked about Croupier was the end credits, but its subsequent success in America has revitalised him. "They're so starved of films with any intellectual content that they went for it," he says.

There will be a full public inquiry into the crimes of Harold Shipman, the doctor convicted of murdering 15 of his patients by lethal injection, the health secretary Alan Milburn said yesterday.

The high court had ordered Mr Milburn to reconsider his decision to hold the inquiry in private and it is likely that the hearing - expected to take months - will be held in Manchester later this year.

A chairman has yet to be appointed after Lord Laming, who would have chaired a private hearing, stood down.

The families of Shipman's victims and eight national newspapers successfully ar gued that there should be a judicial review of Mr Milburn's decision and in July, Lord Justice Kennedy ruled that holding the inquiry in private would breach section 10 of the European convention on human rights. The health secretary was asked to reconsider.

The Department of Health said yesterday the inquiry would be held under the 1921 Tribunals of Inquiry (Evidence) Act which gives the chairman legal powers to compel witnesses to appear and recover any documents. Similar hearings were held following the Aberfan and Dunblane disasters.

It will look at how Shipman was able to murder patients undetected for years, how he obtained drugs and how he was able to cover his tracks by altering medical records and ensuring patients were cremated without postmortem examinations.

Ann Alexander, the solicitor representing 150 families, said she was confident the inquiry would be able to investigate the background to Shipman's murders with the rigour needed to ensure questions were answered and that lessons were learned.

But it is unlikely that Shipman, serving 15 life sentences in Frankland Prison, Durham, will be invited to attend the hearing.

In January, Shipman, a former GP in Hyde, Greater Manchester, was convicted of the murder of 15 patients by lethal diamorphine injections.

Inquests into the deaths of two more patients have recorded verdicts of unlawful killings. A third inquest into the death of Elizabeth Mellor will take place next week.

The death toll from Shipman's killing spree could be as high as 200.

Ms Alexander said the outcome of the inquiry could have widespread implications for family doctors, coroners and for the police.

"The health secretary has obviously taken the sensible course of action and we will make absolutely sure that no stone will be left unturned," she said.

"The inquiry will establish how he was able to get away with killing so many of his patients for so long. It will look at the systems GPs operate within - what controls are in place and how they get hold of drugs."

She added that the public inquiry would also look at how Shipman was able to kill three more women after an initial police investigation in March 1998 had cleared him of any wrongdoing.

Ms Alexander said the relatives of all of the former doctor's victims wanted to hear for themselves what those involved in the Shipman case had to say.

She added that she felt sorry for the families who had been through a long criminal trial, then had to wait almost a year before getting a public inquiry.

Jane Ashton-Hibbert, whose grandmother Hilda Hibbert, 81, died at her home in Hyde while being treated by Shipman in 1996, said she was delighted with the news.

"I am very pleased and I am glad it is going to be a 1921 Act inquiry," she said. "It is going to be very thorough - it's going to have teeth. I think we feel that if it is in the open, people are more inclined to speak freely."

Helen Blackwell, whose mother Bertha Moss, 68, died five years ago, said the public inquiry was vital.

"We need to get it out in the open and to know what went wrong."

During the summer, Sir Richard Branson telephoned this office in something of a lather. He took issue with a piece of commentary which implicitly questioned his motives in bidding to run the national lottery.

His lawyers, Slaughter & May, were on the case, but Sir Richard could not wait.

"Who wrote it?" he demanded. "I did," came the hesitant reply.

"No you didn't. Tom Bower wrote it."

"No, I wrote it."

"Well, you must have spoken to him."

"No, we've never spoken."

At that, Sir Richard softened. The lawyers were called off. He had convinced himself, unnecessarily, that Bower, an investigative author whom he had accused of libel, was teasing out titbits of information ahead of publication of his biography of Britain's Best Loved Entrepreneur.

Ever since it became known that Bower was targeting Branson, there had been a frisson of excitement in the world of Virgin watchers. This was the author who lifted the lid on men like Maxwell and Fayed. If there was any dirt to be dug on the Virgin empire, Bower was the man to dig it. The book was finally published yesterday (Branson, by Tom Bower; £17.99, Fourth Estate) and just a quick read explains Sir Richard's paranoia.

This is 380 pages of unrelenting hostility, charting the businessman's story from his pushy mother to his current, desperate pursuit of the Big Game. It is an addictive read, packed with sex, money, tantrums - top quality tabloidese from beginning to end. Yet it tells us precious little we did not already know about Sir Richard and his business dealings over the past 30 years.

Yes, he duped customs and excise with a mail order record scam back in 1969. Yes, he uses a web of offshore trusts and companies to avoid British tax. And yes, he likes women and has pursued them with some energy.

Two years in the making, the most serious allegation thrown up after 250 interviews concerns the move to take the Virgin group off the stock exchange and back into private hands 12 years ago.

The "explosive" revelation is that while Virgin's investors were offered cash for their shares which valued the business at £248m, Sir Richard had already agreed a deal with a Japanese media firm named Pony Canyon to buy a stake in the newly private Virgin at a price which valued the group at £377m.

The implication is that Sir Richard held back material information, possibly breaking the City's takeover panel code. If Virgin's shareholders had known about the Pony Canyon transaction, they might not have accepted the price offered by Sir Richard - even though this was double the Virgin share price be fore the move to take the company private.

This is a grey area of the law. As Bower knows, the City always distrusts management buyouts such as this; big shareholders assume the managers know more about how much the business is worth. They almost expect to be ripped off.

Bower has failed to deliver proof that Sir Richard is unfit to run the lottery. He has produced an ugly portrait of the man - but he has not penetrated the complex web of Virgin's offshore trusts. A missed opportunity, perhaps.

The world's two largest tobacco manufacturers are being sued over allegations that they are actively involved in organised crime.

Philip Morris and British American Tobacco are accused of widespread smuggling and money laundering in a writ filed by a consortium of Colombian states.

The notice, filed in the US district court in Brooklyn, New York, claims the companies "directly and indirectly" smuggled cigarettes into Colombia.

The pair, it alleges, took part in racketeering activity which included money laundering, wire fraud and mail fraud.

Their actions, states the document, have deprived the republic of Colombia of billions of dollars in taxes, while expanding the market for contraband cigarettes.

A copy of the writ obtained by the Guardian alleges the defendants created a "sophisticated and clandestine smuggling operation" which operated throughout the world.

"Defendants have conceived, directed, controlled and implemented an international conspiracy to defraud the plaintiffs and deprive them of money and property, in order to increase their profits and market share."

The US law firm acting on behalf of the Colombian states, Speiser, Krause, Nolan & Granito, refused to comment.

A New York legal source said that the action was being taken under the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, and the writ would be served on the companies over the next couple of days. They will then have around 20 days to respond.

Clive Bates, of anti-smoking group Ash, said he was pleased legal action was being taken against the companies.

"We want recognition that tobacco companies are intimately involved in large scale smuggling," he said.

Last night, British American Tobacco said it had not been served with a writ, and insisted that any such action would be "defended vigorously".

A spokesman said the company had always worked closely with the Colombian states to eradicate smuggling.

"We reject the US court action and a law suit which al leges actions, including smuggling, as completely without merit," he said. "It is also noteworthy that neither the Colombian government nor the Colombian customs authorities have supported the action by the plaintiffs."

At the time of going to press no comment had been received from Philip Morris.

Morris, whose brands include Marlboro and Virginia Slims, and BAT, which is behind Dunhill and Lucky Strike, are two of the leading forces in an industry riddled with controversy. Recent years have seen an unprecedented number of lawsuits filed across the world against manufacturers.

British American Tobacco already faces an official inquiry by the Department of Trade and Industry into allegations it actively encouraged and profited from cigarette smuggling after a cross-party committee of MPs agreed to demand an investigation.

Earlier this year a jury in the US ordered five of the world's largest companies - including Philip Morris and BAT's US arm Brown & Williamson - to pay a record $145bn (£97bn) for harming the health of hundreds of thousands of smokers in Florida.

By sunrise today the first mass will be over and villagers will disperse to homes and workplaces. This evening they will return to the church to hear if their prayers have been answered.

Judgment day has come but the villagers have been praying for different outcomes. The God they worship has not spared them the tormenting uncertainty over the fate of the conjoined twins Mary and Jodie.

Some defy the priest and secretly pray that this afternoon's ruling by three British court of appeal judges will overrule the parents by allowing the separation to go ahead, killing Mary to save Jodie. Others pray that nature will be allowed to take its course, even if it means both girls will die.

Others pray for a miracle, for the whispers to be true: in the past few days a rumour has spread that Mary does have a functioning heart after all, and could survive without Jodie.

There is no such evidence but this community, whose location cannot be disclosed for legal reasons, is in awe of the dilemma confronting the twins' parents.

Here there is no oak-panelled court room, just cacti, a sea breeze and sunbaked fields, but the arguments that ripple through the community are the same as those convulsing Britain's philosophers, ethicists and law lords.

Here, 95% of the population is practising Catholic and churches sprout from the surrounding hills. Mass is said six times a day, grottoes of the Virgin Mary adorn street corners and abortion is illegal.

Appearing drawn and pale in her living room, the babies' paternal grandmother spoke falteringly. She has been in regular telephone contact with her son but refrains from asking details to avoid upsetting him further.

"It is out of our hands now," she said. "We can only wait to see what happens. It has been so difficult, so difficult. We cannot do anything more except pray."

Half a mile away the maternal grandmother, hanging washing in a garden of fig trees, shook her head and refused to speak. Neighbours said she has become a virtual recluse.

A life-sized statue of the Virgin Mary clutching an infant Jesus gazes out across the dusty, deserted street where the family lives.

A neighbour sweeping her porch questioned whether the birth was a manifestation of God's will. "It is horrible, it just breaks your heart. No family should have to go through that," she said.

"We have been counting down the days [to the ruling] but don't know what to expect. It doesn't seem right that judges make the decision."

But the compassion was tinged with resentment. Mary, the weaker twin, has no viable separate biological existence because she lack lungs and a heart. If they are not separated Jodie will die from the strain of supporting Mary.

The more time elapses the more likely it is that Jodie will become permanently brain damaged, which her parents said would make it almost impossible to rear her on the island.

In a written court statement, the parents said that if they returned with Jodie alive but seriously disabled, some superstitious islanders would regard her as punishment for an earlier sin.

The neighbour said that was nonsense. "Decades ago perhaps, but not now, there is very little stigma left, if any. For years we all took turns looking after a friend's daughter who had Down's syndrome."

Disabled children are no longer hidden and brought to festivals, she said. A respite centre for disabled children and their parents is due to open this year and the hospital several miles from their home is well-equipped and has a paediatrician who is confident of treating all but the most serious cases. A paediatric cardiology unit is 20 minutes away by helicopter.

Tapping his nose, another local said of the written statement: "If it helps them win then OK. Just don't go thinking we are all primitive."

Despite the court ban on naming the family or the area in which they live, everyone here knows who they are, right down to newly arrived tourists. A newspaper which started a website poll on whether Mary and Jodie should be separated recorded 70% in favour of the operation, despite the opposition of the Catholic church which says no life should be taken.

The parents' main argument is that the surgical separation of the twins would kill Mary and wilful killing is against their religious beliefs.

Sitting in a pew near the altar of his Romanesque church, the village priest claimed the congregation had responded positively when he preached against separation.

Immoral

"It is the same principle as organ donation," he said. "Transplants are valid and moral when the donor is dead, but Mary is not dead. She is alive, she is a human being. It is wrong to kill her, no matter how good the intention.

"No one knows how long the twins might live. First the doctors said six months. Now some say two years. Should Mary be denied that? And what if the rumour is true, what if she does have a heart of her own?"

In the square outside the church, a cafe terrace hosted two groups of male villagers discussing the case, their arguments were punctuated by long silences.

A budding consensus that Jodie should be saved broke down over whether Mary's resulting death would be an unintended effect, and thus acceptable, or euthanasia - effectively murder.

One man said both deaths would be tragic but that the two innocents, baptised in Manchester, would be guaranteed eternal peace in the kingdom of heaven. Those on either side shook their heads but said nothing.

They agreed to meet again today for evening mass. A friend of the family stood up to leave. "We can talk all day about what the parents should do, and what we would do if we were in their shoes, but the truth of it is we don't have a clue. Only if it happens to your own blood can you know."

The judges

The three judges hearing the case of conjoined twins Jodie and Mary have, in effect, the awesome responsibility of ruling which of the sisters has the greatest claim to life.

Yet the legal system makes it almost impossible for the public to examine the judges' personal or religious views - views which might influence their outlook.

British law insists that a judge's "religion, ethnic or national origin, gender, age, class, means or sexual orientation" should not be a factor in deciding whether he or she is fit to hear a case. It could be said that as they base their decisions on the law rather than their beliefs then their own faith is irrelevant.

But some observers have argued that as religion has played an important role in the case - the parents have said they cannot agree to the operation to separate the twins because of their faith and the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Westminster, Cormac Murphy-O'Connor has been allowed to make his submissions - the beliefs of the judges could be relevant.

All three judges have religious backgrounds, though they have declined to talk about their beliefs. They are also family men with 13 children between them and the senior judge, Lord Justice Ward, has twin daughters.

Lord Justice Ward , 62, is a former pupil of the Christian Brothers college in Pretoria, South Africa. The college offered what it describes as "holistic education based on Catholic traditions". He married in a Church of England ceremony in Somerset in 1963 while at Cambridge University and was called to the Bar the following year.

He had one son and two daughters by his first marriage and was divorced in 1982. He remarried the following year and had twin daughters in 1984. From 1988 to 1995 he was a judge in the high court's family division and has been a lord justice in the court of appeal since 1995.

At times he brought religion into the hearing. He said: "It was not God's will that [Mary, the weaker twin] should live because it was not born with the capability of living." He also said that one law we have was "handed down from Mount Sinai - thou shalt not kill".

Lord Justice Brooke , 64, is from a family with a strong Anglican tradition. His maternal grandfather was a canon and his uncle a former dean and rector of St Albans. His brother, the former Northern Ireland secretary and Conservative party chairman, Peter Brooke, was chairman of the National Conference of Student Christian Movement and a lay adviser to St Paul's cathedral.

A father of three sons and one daughter, Lord Justice Brooke is a former chairman of the Law Commission who became a Lord Justice of Appeal in 1996.

He brought religion into the case when he pointed out that much of today's law is founded on case law made by judges "long ago" who based their findings on Judaeo-Christian principles.

Lord Justice Walker , 62, was educated at one of Britain's most famous Catholic schools, Downside in Bath, which was founded by Benedictine monks in the 17th century. He married in Hampstead register office, in north London, in 1962 and has one son and three daughters.

Seen by insiders as the most "intellectually rigorous" of the trio, he practised at the Chancery Bar between 1961 and 1994 before being promoted first as a judge of the high court chancery division and since 1997 has been a lord justice of appeal

Lord Melchett's surprise victory in Norfolk crown court has run a coach and horses through Michael Meacher's patiently crafted solution for dealing with the British public's virulent opposition to genetically modified crops. Contrary to expectation, the jury cleared Lord Melchett and 27 other Greenpeace campaigners of criminal damage on Tuesday despite their own admission that they had destroyed a GM maize crop. What now lies in ruins is the government's approach of allowing farm-scale crop trials, but banning commercial growing of GM crops until the trials are complete. The verdict is a green light to protesters and signals to farmers that such is the public distrust of GM, their fields have little or no legal protection.

What will be worrying Mr Meacher is that the ban was effectively a voluntary agreement by the seed companies. Given that the GM seeds had already got EU approval, they have every right to sell them in this country and they would have the backing of European law to do so. They sensibly know such a route would be a public relations fiasco. For the politicians, it would be a disaster, a dangerous conflation of two of the British public's pet hates: GM and Brussels. The task ahead for Mr Meacher is how to keep the seed companies on board.

The bigger political challenge - which looks near impossible - is how to convince the British public that, at the very least, it should allow scientists the opportunity to find out what impact GM crops have on the environment. Norfolk crown court's jury showed how profound the public's unease is. There is little point arguing that this depth of feeling obviously owes much to the catastrophe of BSE, or that other agricultural innovations in the past 50 years - such as the use of pesticides - have caused far worse environmental damage. The opposition is stubborn and incidents such as the GM rape crops inadvertently planted earlier this year and then destroyed only reinforce the belief that this technology is impossible to control.

Once again, sharply on the heels of the fuel crisis, the limits of government power have been starkly exposed by a small, committed group who can call on unexpected reserves of support among the general public. In a final irony, it was the very group that last week defied the law outside oil refinery gates, the farmers, who this week are busy asserting the rule of law.

The night in Belgrade belongs to the dogs - 60,000 of them now run wild because people can no longer afford to feed them. The city authorities are so broke that they frequently run out of drugs to put them down. So the dogs are clubbed to death instead. In the early morning the smell of freshly rotting rubbish hangs in the streets.

Yugoslavia's presidential elections take place on Sunday and the polls predict that Vojislav Kostunica, a previously unknown lawyer, will beat Slobodan Milosevic - despite the election rigging that Milosevic is famous for, and despite the fact that in Serbia nobody ever wins elections except Milosevic. But if Kostunica wins, it's likely that Milosevic will simply use the media he controls to declare victory anyway. He could do that as early as 10 o'clock on Sunday night, just two hours after the polls close and even before the polling boxes make it to the central sorting office. Welcome to Serbia 2000, where Serbs again will be left with no option but to go out on the streets. But the question is how many still have the energy left to go out and protest again.

In the winter of 1996, 50,000 people came out to protest against the rigged local elections, and the police special forces crushed them. They were crushed again in March this year when they came out against him on the anniversary of the war in Kosovo. And on Sunday, Milosevic fights not just for his political future, but to avoid spending the rest of his life in the Dutch seaside prison where the international court in the Hague sends its guilty men. "If we win, it will be great," said one of his long-time party workers. "If we lose, they will lynch us."

There are 120,000 police at Milosevic's disposal, and all holiday leave has been cancelled. They will do the job they have done in previous protests.

On Planet Serbia, closed off from the world, hundreds of thousands of people have turned the frustration and anger of Milosevic's last 12 years of rule into hatred for both him and his wife. He has been the force behind the three bloody wars - in Croatia, Bosnia and Kosovo - as he tried to use nationalism to secure his own political future. Milosevic, the puppetmaster of the Balkans, has led his people into the wilderness, turning Serbs into international outcasts. A million of them were driven from their homes in those wars, and before their eyes, Yugoslavia, once the wealthiest, healthiest and most beautiful country in eastern Europe, has shrunk from 250,000 square kilometres of sea and mountains to a violent ghetto a quarter that size.

Milosevic will be 60 next birthday. His only vices - apart from an obsession with remaining in power - are whisky and Cuban cigars. Both he and his wife have tragic personal histories. His father, a teacher, shot himself when Milosevic was 21. His mother, also a teacher, killed herself 10 years later. But a former Yugoslav ambassador once said that "in his presence you can feel his strength of personality. You just feel yourself shrinking down in the armchair when he begins to talk. He is a powerful man". Richard Holbrooke, who chaired the Dayton peace talks in 1995, said he had a great sense of humour; even the waitresses in the Dayton airbase canteen were charmed by him.

He met his wife, Mira Markovic, at school in Pozarevac. Her mother was tortured and executed by the Gestapo in 1944 as one of Tito's partisans. They have two children: Marija, a 34-year-old former journalist; and Marko, a 26-year-old former racing driver who runs his own Milosevic mafia in their home town.

In the foyer of a Belgrade police station a nurse is trying to sort out her papers and wants to know if there are any jobs in England so she can get out of "this madhouse" before the elections. Behind the desk a fat, almost friendly policeman is frowning into his big yellowing ledger. He sits behind chocolate-coloured tinted glass; a full ashtray and grubby overflowing trays of carbon-copied identity papers. It's like being in eastern Europe in 1989.

Kostunica, who presents the first real political challenge to Milosevic, is a former communist but a man with clean hands and no past. The only dirt the regime has managed to get on him is to accuse him of keeping 17 cats - which, according to an editorial in Milosevic's paper Politika, shows that, like the average cat, he is untrustworthy and selfish. The editorial also said that he is supported by "Gays, lesbians and feminists".

On each of the 10 floors of my apartment block "Gotov Je" - he's finished - is plastered above the door of the lift. The opposition movement now claims to have 100,000 activists campaigning against Milosevic, but he is far from finished. Until election day he is fighting for his political life, primarily through the TV station he took over 13 years ago when he first came to power.

We are watching the news in a top-floor flat. Outside, across the city's skyline, most of the damage done in Nato's 74 days of bombing has disappeared. The news begins with an eight-minute item about the reopening of the chemical plant outside Belgrade. We see a crowd of slightly distracted looking workers shouting "Slobo, Slobo". The next 12 minutes are election speeches from around the country with "Slobo, Slobo" being chanted constantly in the background. The captain of the national volleyball team calls on people to vote for Milosevic. One hour into the news and they move on to the 100,000 houses that Milosevic will build in the next 10 years.

Sylvia, the mother of the house, stands up. "I can't watch it. I hate him. I could kill him with my bare hands." She is 40 years old and has a masters degree in engineering. "He stole the best years of my life. We have no money, my car is 13 years old. I survive by smuggling sanitary towels and chocolate from Romania. If he wins again there is no future for us."

Sylvia escapes to the kitchen. The news goes on about another new electricity plant being opened; then finally there's a mention of the opposition. They are all "fifth columnists" and "traitors". The hour and 48 minutes of Milosevic propaganda mentions his name more than 40 times and ends with the news that he is leading the "global battle against the agents of fascism".

Milosevic controls all the media, allowing only a few independents to preach to the converted in Belgrade. The rest of the country receive only his message, and it has worked. The latest polls say that Milosevic could legitimately poll more than 1.5m votes and Kostunica is expected to win by as few as 700,000. But Milosevic is free to fix the ballot in Serb regions of Kosovo and the sister state of Montenegro.

His biggest supporters are among the old former communists who hark back to Tito, like 64-year-old Dorde Erdeljan and his 61-year-old wife Stava. They say they watch the news every night - never miss it. "If it wasn't for Milosevic being so strong we would have had Nato troops on the streets of Belgrade," says Dorde. "Kostunica's coalition are traitors who would betray our country." Instead of blaming Milosevic for the hardships of the past 10 years, they point to sanctions and a western conspiracy. "Look at what happened in Britain over the petrol prices - your country would have collapsed in six months if you had to put up with what Serbia has been forced to suffer."

The only dissenter on the street is Dobrivoic Radanovic, a 50-year-old former boxer and mechanic. "Of course I'm voting for the opposition. The only people who won't are the old, the army and police."

"What will happen then?"

"Nothing. People will protest and that will be it. The police will crush them and that will be it. We are a special people, the Serbs. The Turks ruled us and we got used to being oppressed."

Jovan Dulovic works for the small independent magazine Vreme. He specialises in police affairs. "The special intervention force can be in Belgrade in a few hours. They are the cream of the force, usually athletes and young guys who do weights. In any normal country of our size the police force should be about 30,000; here we've got 120,000. If the people keep going on the streets, the police will beat them. I don't expect them to do anything immediately - he will wait to see how the protests go. Then if they continue it will be very brutal."

Milosevic is on the campaign trail, appearing at organised mass rallies. On Monday night, the TV broadcasts a ceremony showing 10,089 people gathering to join his party. Each was presented with a red rose and given 100 German marks for turning up. "We are living through some sort of tragic comic opera which might look funny but it is very, very dangerous," says Lubodrag Stojadivovic, a former spokesman for the Yugoslav army who was sacked for writing an open letter protesting about political interference, especially by Milosevic's wife in the army.

I think it is possible that the police will be used in a massive and brutal way. If that doesn't work his last card will be the army, but that is a very dangerous card to play - no matter what the generals say, the soldiers will not go against the people."

The town where Milosevic and his wife began their lives looks like a pleasant place in the early autumn. All along the main street there are white banners in red letters that read "Choose people not Nato" and "For Yugoslavia". There's not a single poster or banner for the opposition in sight. The chestnut trees in the square were turning red when Markovic went there last week to address a public rally calling on her town and her nation to support her husband.

"Only about 2,000 people turned up," says Mile Yeljkovic, a journalist with Beta, the independent newsagency. "Even those people were bused in. I heard afterwards that she was in tears, she couldn't believe there were so few people."

On Sunday, and in the days that follow, Serbia will find out what they already know - that Milosevic will play God to the end. He has no choice. Perhaps that's why this city of Belgrade on this warm September day is full mostly of exhaustion and despair. "Pandora's box has been opened and the only thing left inside for us now is hope," said a beautiful student, plastering opposition posters on a baker's wall. She is 19, and not so tired.

Life and times of Milosevic

Born:
August 29 1941, in Pozarevac, Serbia. Following the suicide of his father in 1962, Milosevic was raised by his mother, who also killed herself in 1973.

Early years:
Graduated in law from Belgrade University in 1964 and pursued a business career. He was chief of the state-owned gas company Technogas 1968-78, and member of the board of directors of Beobank (United Bank of Belgrade) 1978-82.

Political career:
Joined the communist party of Yugoslavia when he was 18. Entered politics in 1984. In 1987 he became leader of the Serbian communists. Elected president of the Serbian Republic in 1989. The following year he turned the League of Communists of Serbia into the Socialist party of Serbia and was returned to power in the election of December 1990.

Croatia:
Serb forces bombard cities including Dubrovnik and Vukovar as the conflict escalates in 1991. Croatian independence recognised by the EC the following year.

Bosnia-Herzegovina:
International recognition of the area as an independent state in April 1992 leads to civil war. Thousands of Muslims massacred by Serbs at Srebrenica in the summer of 1995. Milosevic agrees to peace in the Dayton accord in November of that year.

Kosovo:
The 1998 offensive by Serb forces against the Kosovo Liberation Army leads to the 78-day bombing of Serbia by Nato forces, March to June 1999, which ends when Milosevic agrees to withdraw his troops.

Edited extracts from Charles Kennedy's speech in Bournemouth yesterday:

Potentially, politics is at a crossroads. We saw that last week. The opinion polls have recorded that this week. That's been the backdrop for this, I think, one of our most successful conferences ever. Politics is about leading. But politics is also about listening. The events of the past 10 days, have demonstrated, graphically, that the current government, neither leads nor listens enough.

People want a better level of political dialogue. Just look at the crime debate. Ann Widdecombe and Jack Straw. They're competing in a dismal Dutch auction. Going for lowest common denominator politics. Over-claim. Over-blame. Over-reach. Undermine the entire point of the political process along the way.

Let me be quite clear. I'm not one of those who believe that all Britain's problems began on the first of May 1997. But Labour's poverty of ambition is quite remarkable. With a parliamentary majority - of 179, they behave like John Major did - with a majority of three.

Ethical

It's all about what will play well in the opinion polls. Britain was promised an ethical foreign policy. Britain demands legislation on the arms trade. But instead we get arms sales to Indonesia.

And all too often, they seem scared of their own shadows. Remember that leaked prime ministerial memo? What was it he said? "A sense that the government ... are somehow out of touch with gut British instincts".

So I ask you, Labour voter last time, maybe for the first time was it? Did you believe, that things could only get better? And have they? Millions of people believed it. Millions of people are disappointed.

The Conservatives won't improve these things for you. But the Liberal Democrats can. We can improve a lot on Labour. They are continually terrified to be called the party of boom and bust. That old Labour habit of splashing out in their first years in power, and then having to cut back at the end. Gordon Brown certainly hasn't done that. He's cut back and now he's splashing out. Bust followed by pre-election boom. We said that wasn't good enough. I'd like to think he saw the light. But the truth is, he felt the heat.

Now what of the Conservative party? Today, I want to address the millions of previous Conservative voters, who feel that William Hague's party offers them - nothing. I share many of the values, the beliefs, the concerns, of the people who used to be called One Nation Conservatives. Tolerance, decency, fair play.

If you believe in those things, and you look at your party. And it's not got room any more, at the top table, for the likes of Ken Clarke, Michael Heseltine, Chris Patten. Then your party's got no room for you.

To you, I say this. You have friends in the Liberal Democrats. Come and talk to us. You will be very, very welcome. What's gone wrong with the Conservative party - oh, so wrong - is not even so much the individuals, it's the issues and the instincts which today guide William Hague's Conservative party.

William jumps in with both feet, in the wrong place, at the wrong time, and for the wrong reasons. Desperate for a headline, desperate for a quote. Desperate to get attention. He's the world's first unpopular populist.

So how come the Tories have come up in the polls? I know the answer. It's not William's popularity. It's the people round about him that the country's warming to. It must be John Redwood, Michael Portillo and Ann Widdecombe the country loves.

Just look at what William's been up to this year. January -patient's guarantee. Ditched. February - tax guarantee. Ditched. March - the moral case for low taxation. Ditched with the tax guarantee. April - bogus asylum seekers. May - Romsey. June. He was quiet in June. Perhaps he had a 14-pint hangover. Or perhaps it was that Romsey hangover.

Record

Remember their record? Recessions. Crime doubled. Larger class sizes. Fewer nurses. Pensions slashed. Interest rates - through the roof. Arms to Iraq. BSE. Cash for questions. Sleaze. It must never, ever, be allowed to happen again.

William Hague is not the serious leader of a serious political party. That's the serious point. We are serious. Our pur pose is here in this document. It's the F word. Freedom. That's why we're in politics. We want politicians to promote freedom for all. So people can make the most of their lives. I am determined we will get our message across.

But as part of that, it is vital, absolutely vital, that we persuade people, that for every area where government can do more, there's an area where government should be doing less, or doing different.

We would scrap a range of regulations, that burden small businesses. We will cut bureaucracy in schools.

Tax and spend? Every party taxes and spends. But our priorities, are the people's priorities. That's what freedom means. It's not left of Labour. It's not right of Labour. It's ahead of Labour.

It's also honest. Where there is a cost, we say how we will pay for it. Saying that if necessary, we will pay for better schools, by asking everybody to pay just 1p more on the basic rate of income tax. And to fund decent pensions, we will ask those fortunate enough to earn over £100,000 per year, to pay a little more.

On health: Nurses and doctors - more of them. Prescription charges - abolish them. Eye and dental check-ups - free once again. Schools and colleges, cut class sizes for all 5 to 11 year olds. Abolish tuition fees for higher education.

And what about the pensioners? Forgotten and insulted by Gordon Brown. So we will give pensioners more, above inflation. £5 extra every week for every pensioner, If you're over 75, it's going to be £10 extra. If you're over 80, it's going to be £15 extra. Now that will make a real difference.

We say that a clean environ ment relates to health. To poverty. To transport. To education. To civil liberties. We understand that, instinctively so. And again, we're honest. We're clear, fuel taxes should be used, to improve the environment. In the months and years to come, we have got to get that message across. Positive gain, not pain.

Single currency

And let me say something about the single currency. As pro-Europeans we are not in favour, of rushing into the euro head first.

We don't believe Europe is perfect. And we will work to see that reform takes place. But we do believe that Britain can and must lead in Europe. Lead reform in Europe.

That's why, earlier this year, I asked a panel of experts, to report on what the government should be doing. And if the government chooses to ignore the experts, British businesses will lose, British workers will lose, British consumers will lose. So those of us in favour of the euro, must go out there and argue the case. We cannot sit on our hands.

This has been an outstanding year for the Liberal Democrats. The local elections - our biggest ever share of the national vote. Sandra's triumph in Romsey. At the next election, I believe we will win more votes, and more seats. 1997 was a staging post. It wasn't a high water mark.

So we must go into the next election, and tell people about our message of freedom. The difference between the Liberal Democrats and the disaster of William Hague's Party. The difference between the Liberal Democrats and the disappointment that Labour has become. Go out there and tell it to people as it is. What you see is what you get. This is what we will deliver. A truly modern, truly free, 21st century Britain. A Liberal Democrat Britain.

Britain's most dangerous sex offenders could be held indefinitely in prison under new plans being considered by the Liberal Democrats.

Simon Hughes, the party's home affairs spokesman, said the use of "indefinite sentences" would not necessarily mean prisoners gained longer sentences, but there would be a more controlled release of them into society.

Serious sex offenders would be given a minimum tariff, but it would be up to judges to assess whether satisfactory arrangements had been made for them to be let out.

Mr Hughes' call for a review of the current sentencing policy came as the party addressed an issue which has been a national preoccupation following the abduction and murder of eight-year-old Sarah Payne in July. There has been strong pressure for a "Sarah's law" which would allow parents access to the sex offenders' register.

Earlier this month the government ruled this out, but introduced other proposals, including fingerprinting and photographing offenders on their release and life bans on them contacting their victims.

Indefinite sentences are not an option at present unless a serious sex offender has re-offended, but the Home Office is looking at applying this to a small number of extremely dangerous sex offenders under separate legislation.

Yesterday Liberal Democrats called for "serious consideration" to be given to this measure, and called for the victims of sex offenders to be told where and when their abusers would be released. Proposing the motion, Gary Glover said: "Victims of serious crimes should not be terrified day after day, week after week by fear of meeting offenders."

Delegates also called for sex offenders convicted outside Britain to be placed on the register when they enter this country, and for the public to have access to this. But there was condemnation of the News of the World and its recent campaign to name and shame paedophiles, widely criticised by police and probation services at the time on the grounds it would drive offenders underground.

"It didn't take the News of the World to make the world aware of this problem," said Mr Hughes. "The News of the World were entirely irresponisble and entirely self serving."

Collapsed talks between British Airways and KLM Dutch Airlines , after the two failed to agree on the structure of a joint airline, is the latest disappointment for BA.

Rod Eddington - who, according to one profile of the new chief executive, was nicknamed God at university due to his academic and sporting prowess - has become the latest BA boss to hit turbulence. BA has fallen from the dizzy heights of profitability to losses.

A few months after Bob Ayling became head of BA on January 1 1996, the airline announced record pre-tax profits of £474m. A lucrative alliance with American Airlines was looking likely and Mr Ayling had embarked on a £1bn cost-cutting programme. Even after privatisation BA was still a national institution, the country's only flag carrier.

Then came the problems. In 1997 staff morale hit an all time low following a three-day cabin crew strike. The incident cost the company £125m.

Graffiti on the walls at BA's headquarters summed up the mood: "First we had King, then we had Marshall, now we are just Ayling."

More public embarrassments were to follow. The redesign of the airline's tailfins became a national joke and the airline faced derision as it was forced into an climbdown. The re-design was part of a £60m corporate revamp.

The proposed tie-up with American Airlines became bogged down in regulatory disputes. Mr Ayling had worked hard to join the two companies. It would have given them control of 70% of flights across the north Atlantic. Opposition from regulators and other airlines meant that it failed.

In February 1999 BA reported its first loss since it was privatised in 1987, falling £75m into the red. The failure of its London Eye big wheel to open on time was another public humiliation.

Mr Ayling was replaced by Mr Eddington, but the new man's reign has got off to a bad start.

Yugoslavia's army chief ratcheted up the tension yesterday ahead of Sunday's election by claiming that Nato countries planned to send in special forces to help rivals of President Slobodan Milosevic seize power.

General Nebojsa Pavkovic's assertion sounded like a pretext for Mr Milosevic to clamp down on protesters or declare a state of emergency if he loses on Sunday - as all opinion polls predict he will. Voters will be choosing a federal parliament, local mayors and the Yugoslav presidency.

The army knew of a plan, Gen Pavkovic said, under which there would be disturbances on Sunday "provoked by special units of foreign armed forces who would be infiltrated into Yugoslav territory on that day".

They would come from the Serb part of Bosnia, from Montenegro and from Kosovo. They would dress in Yugoslav army and police uniforms, he said, and would stage provocations "under the guise of extending aid to the 'victors' - the opposition".

"Threats are being addressed to our country at the moment and as a serious army it is our duty to make all the preparations to prevent any surprises," he added.

Although the general also said the army would accept a genuine opposition victory, he is a Milosevic loyalist. Mr Milosevic has called the vote a choice between "patriotism and treachery" and the hint of military action worries western policymakers.

European Union foreign ministers offered voters a massive inducement this week to oust the president by announcing that foreign sanctions would be lifted if there was "democratic change".

The chief opposition candidate, Vojislav Kostunica, is a moderate nationalist who has walked a careful line in recent days by strongly criticising the United States while showing more sympathy for European positions. But he still calls for the unconditional lifting of sanctions and has denounced Nato's bombing of Yugoslavia last year.

While western governments can offer an end to sanctions, they cannot agree on what to do if Mr Milosevic "steals" Sunday's election by declaring victory on the basis of fraud and ballot-rigging.

Diplomats are uncertain how the president will play the election and are unwilling to speculate on his options or their reactions. The only certainties are that Mr Milosevic called the polls early thinking he would win easily because of the opposition's disunity, and that he is as surprised as any one by his opponents' strength.

The International Crisis Group, a think-tank that aims to strengthen the capacity of the international community to anticipate conflict, and which has good contacts in Washington and London, this week outlined four scenarios for Sunday's poll.

Fearing defeat, the Yugoslav president may call it off after "provoking some sort of internal crisis through a staged terrorist attack or simulated military coup, or major disruption in Montenegro". This is unlikely, says the ICG, because it would damage his image of being confident and in control.

Scenario two, is "the big steal" in which he cheats. A third option is that he plays by the rules on Sunday and accepts defeat knowing that under the constitution he need not hand over power until his mandate ends next August. In the meantime he transfers all power to the Serbian presidency and organises an election victory in Serbia next spring, leaving Mr Kostunica to inherit an empty shell as Yugoslav president.

The last option is again that Mr Milosevic accepts a Kostunica victory but over the next few months allows Montenegro to secede, thereby destroying Yugoslavia and leaving Mr Kostunica with no role.

Like most observers, the ICG believes the "big steal" is the likeliest. All will depend on the opposition's reaction, it says.

The opposition might accept cheating in the presidential vote while using its new strength in parliament and town halls to consolidate power for the long haul. Alternatively, it may mount street protests and confront the government, but Mr Kostunica has repeatedly said he does not want bloodshed.

The first evidence emerged yesterday of vote rigging for this Sunday's crucial presidential election in Yugoslavia, as fears grew that President Slobodan Milosevic would use any tactic to stay in power.

The discovery of a completed ballot slip containing a vote for the president adds to concerns that fraud on a massive scale would enable Mr Milosevic to overcome the lead of his chief rival, Vojislav Kostunica.

The slip was found in in the letterbox of an electoral monitoring group, the Centre for Free Elections (Cesid). The slip, bearing the official stamp, carries the name of the five candidates for president. Slobodan Milosevic is circled.

"We are deeply concerned. Is it possible that those ballots are circling Serbia?" asked Slobodanka Nedovic of Cesid, who was told by election officials that they would "discuss the problem tomorrow".

Many in Belgrade are not surprised by the find. Milan Nikolic, director of the Centre for Policy Studies, said: "They will use every means possible because they are in very bad shape."

Analysts say Kosovo provides fertile ground for dirty tricks - 300 polling stations will be open, but it will hard for non-governmental groups to verify the results. A second area of concern lies in the two electoral districts in southern Serbia: Prokuplje and Vranje, and in Montenegro.

In addition, several hundred thousand ethnic Albanians remain registered to vote in Yugoslavia and analysts fear their votes could be appropriated.

The Kostunica coalition, the Democratic Opposition of Serbia (Dos), is taking strenuous measures to curb voting fraud.

Its campaign manager, Zoran Djindjic, said almost every polling station in Serbia and Montenegro will have a Dos member on its electoral board, but that the coalition had been denied such representation in southern Serbia and Kosovo.

He said Dos was unable to monitor much of the election process. "The voting lists are made by police. The polls are controlled by the government. The courts are controlled by the Socialist party [of Milosevic] and Yugoslav United Left party [of Mr Milosevic's wife]."

He said the authorities turned down an opposition request to follow ballots from the polling station to the headquarters of the federal election commission and to watch the data being put into computers.

An application by Cesid for its observers to check the polls was also rejected. Cesid staff have been targeted across Serbia, with secret police raiding offices and making arrests.

A serial rapist was yesterday convicted of his third sex attack across a 17 year period, after a law change allowed evidence from five previous rape trials he has faced to be laid before the jury.

Nicholas Edwards was jailed for life for the rape of a 23-year-old woman in 1998, after the Old Bailey heard it fitted a pattern consistent with five previous attacks over 14 years.

In an unprecedented move, the judge, Leonard Gerber, allowed the jury to hear evidence from four woman who went to court claiming Edwards raped them only to see him acquitted, and from a woman whom he was jailed for raping.

Before the trial began, the House of Lords agreed to make a significant change in English criminal law to allow the "similar fact" evidence to be put before the jury. But civil liberties campaigners last night warned that the Lords' judgment risked increasing miscarriages of justice.

In the charge he faced and in his previous trials, Edwards, 39, had claimed the woman had consented to sex, and juries had to decide between his word and that of the woman.

The Old Bailey jury did not hear from another woman whom Edwards had been convicted of raping at knifepoint in 1981, and another whose allegations he was cleared of, as they could not be traced.

Edwards was yesterday convicted solely for his attack on a young mother, Miss D, whom he raped in August 1998 in his flat in Sydenham, southeast London.

As in previous rape allegations against him, Edwards approached the woman and initially appeared charming.

As in at least one other allegation, he called her a "bitch" during the attack and ordered her to strip before pinning her under him and forcing her to have unprotected intercourse.

With Miss D, Edwards's mood changed in a "Jekyll and Hyde" way immediately before the rape, matching the testimony of the five other women.

Miss D, who had a five-month-old son, was left so traumatised that she was unable to breast feed her child.

She also bathed in bleach and Dettol to try and "wash him away".

Detective Sergeant Paul Astbury, who led the gathering of evidence, said Edwards had used knowledge gained from his previous trials to rape in a way that minimised his chances of being convicted: "As he was planning them, he was formulating his own defence ... knowing exactly what it took to get off, knowing exactly what was required for the police to prove his guilt.

"He is one of the most dangerous individuals I have come across. Without the similar fact evidence, the chances of securing a conviction would be less than average."

Privately, police officers believe he could have raped far more than the eight known about. Another two women have come forward since the Old Bailey trial began.

The prosecutor, David Perry QC, reading a victim impact statement from Miss D after the verdict, said: "She cannot kiss her boyfriend on the lips. She has never kissed anyone on the lips since the rape. She still suffers from flashbacks and nightmares and thinks she has changed since. She cannot get the face of the defendant's face out of her head and has become depressed."

A 42-year-old woman, Miss R, who saw Edwards's acquitted of charges of raping her in a churchyard in 1991, said she had to testify at the Old Bailey: "It has got him off the streets before he cannot attack other women. When I heard he had struck again, I wanted to do something to help put this man behind bars.

"He turned from a charming individual into a monster."

Mary Cuneen, director of policy for the civil rights group Liberty, said: "The House of Lords judgment goes too far. The facts of this case are obviously horrendous. In effect you are judging somebody's guilt not on the basis of the evidence of the offence they have committed, but on the basis of other matters.

"Clearly there is a strong interest in prosecuting rape cases properly, but there is a danger that the House of Lords has not had proper regard for the principles of general fairness."

The Lords dismissed defence arguments that allowing similar fact evidence to be heard would be prejudicial.

Judge Gerber said Edwards should serve a minimum of seven years imprisonment for attacking Miss D before he could be considered for parole: "You humiliated her and have not shown one iota of remorse."

Detective Chief Inspector Jim Webster appealed for any other women with information about Edwards to contact the police.

As Nicholas Edwards last night began a life sentence, the fact that he was no longer a danger to women was of little comfort to the victims whose lives he damaged.

One had an abortion, one is still haunted by the memory 16 years on, another was never able to breastfeed her child, another is on anti-depressants, another cannot kiss or be kissed on the lips.

The legal system that Edwards exploited to get away with a campaign of rape pulled out all the stops to convict him of the eighth sex attack charge he has faced since 1981.

Edwards had asked the jury at the Old Bailey to believe that so many women were accusing him of rape because he was "unlucky".

In a totally different sense to what he meant, he was right. Less than one in 10 rapes reported to police result in conviction. Researchers believe those attacks which are reported also represent a tenth of the real total, meaning the chances of Edwards being convicted yesterday were less than one in100.

For 17 years he carried out a string of sex attacks, exploiting his knowledge of the legal system through his seven previous rape trials to gain acquittal. There was inconclusive or no medical or forensic evidence supporting the women's claims.

Detective Sergeant Paul Astbury, who built the case against Edwards, said: "I think the only purpose in his life was sex."

Police found it hard to piece together a coherent picture of his life. Edwards claimed to have fathered six children, but was never part of a stable family unit.

"What is more frightening is he has integrated into society perfectly normally, he's held down a job, he's fathered children," said Mr Astbury.

Edwards's family were noticeable by their absence from the three-week trial, with one of his daughters attending briefly.

From the witness box Edwards bragged of having lost his virginity at 13. He claimed, police believe falsely, to have slept with 2,000 women, and of having six children with five women.

His counsel, Richard Benson QC, said that Edwards had "the morals of an alley cat".

But Mr Benson continued: "No matter how much you want to doctor him, you cannot convict him of rape. His 2001 sexual scalps weigh so heavily on his belt it's a wonder whether he can stand up straight.

"If he's right about his 2000 women sexual odyssey, he's little more than a walking Viagra tablet."

But there was no levity when his victims testified. They sobbed as they recounted their ordeals.

He was convicted for his first rape, committed in 1981 at knifepoint in his car in High Wycombe. He was charged with a total of five rapes carried out while he lived in the town, and for another three after he moved to London, where he worked as a welder.

The prosecution strategy that led to the groundbreaking House of Lords ruling was masterminded by Treasury counsel David Perry, representing the crown.

With consent the key issue, it allowed him to argue to the jury that his case relied on more than Miss D's word against Edwards's. It allowed him to say the attack on Miss D fitted Edwards's method of raping.

Mr Perry listed 18 similarities between the various rape cases, among them the fact that Edwards maintained they all consented to sex; that victims spoke of him "engineering" the initial meeting; that he took them out on a date; that they described him as "friendly and charming"; and that he "flipped" very quickly from being pleasant to an "aggressive and intimidating person'"

Edwards also ordered the women to strip; the victims all talked of being "frozen" with fear; Edwards was always in control of the situation, ordering his victims to move their bodies as if it was normal intercourse; Edwards never used contraception; once intercourse was over "he reverted to his former self" and there was conversation from him as if nothing untoward had happened.

Twice Edwards called the victims "bitches", twice he said there was no point in them screaming because no one would hear. Two women, one a virgin, said they were raped in the same south London churchyard.

Mr Perry said: "If the defendant is telling the truth you may think he is a very unlucky man.

"Does lightning strike seven times? In the Guinness Book of Records the record for lightning striking a man is nine times and that may be so. But we are not talking about natural phenomena, we are talking about human behaviour.

"The statistical probability is that each of these women are not going to make identical allegations."

Sue Lees, of the University of North London, has studied the crash in conviction rates in rape cases and Edwards's career as a sex attacker: "Juries do not expect serial rapists to be nicely dressed, ordinary men, and don't know about the tactics serial rapists use.

"The balance of the courts is in favour of the defendant, the victim can't meet the prosecution beforehand, and past convictions cannot be introduced except at the discretion of the judge."

The legal device used to introduce the evidence of past attacks of which Edwards was cleared will present prosecutors with new weapons in cases against serial rapists and serial paedophiles.

Considering the rape of Miss D, the jury decided there was too much coincidence in the torrid life of Nicholas Edwards.

Several women said that after raping them, he used the identical words, "I suppose you are going to call this rape". That is what the jury did.
