Why does Andrew Lloyd Webber generate such loathing? A friend, on hearing that I was interviewing him, told me she would never speak to me again if I said he was a good composer. He was, she insisted, a borrower of other people's tunes and Rachmaninov should have got a royalty for Aspects of Love. Victor Lewis-Smith, the scabrous TV critic of the London Evening Standard, said much the same thing this week, adding for good measure that Lord L-W was "plug ugly".

The latter can be quickly dealt with: he isn't particularly. He would be the first to admit that he is no oil painting, but then neither is Lewis-Smith. The music is trickier. There are clearly many influences on Lloyd Webber's tunes and you often feel you've heard them somewhere before, but nothing has ever been proved and litigants who have pursued him on grounds of plagiarism have always lost.

Lloyd Webber's new show, The Beautiful Game, opens next Tuesday at London's Cambridge Theatre. It marks a key moment in his career, because his last two shows - Sunset Boulevard and Whistle Down the Wind - failed to set the West End on fire and only two years ago he appeared to be on the point of abandoning musicals. "I thought I'd write an art book or something," he said.

That was before a dinner with Ben Elton that, in the best let's-do-the-show-right-here traditions, changed everything. "I thought I was beginning to tread water a bit with Whistle Down the Wind," Lloyd Webber told me when we met at the Really Useful Group's really lovely office in Soho. "So when Ben said he would be interested in writing with me it was a breath of fresh air. If musical theatre is to have a relevance, from time to time we have to take on subjects that are challenging, or we might as well be doing nothing but revivals. You can't go on looking back, and maybe I'm guilty of having looked back a little bit myself in one or two of my recent things. Now I feel refreshed."

In late 1998, Lloyd Webber had approached Elton to provide some new material for Starlight Express. Elton said no to that but suggested, as the wine flowed, that they collaborate on a contemporary piece. Lloyd Webber recalled seeing a TV programme about a group of Irish youngsters who played in a non-sectarian football team and, a few weeks later, Elton turned in a 40-page synopsis.

Lloyd Webber has taken some stick for "stealing" the story of the Belfast-based Star of the Sea team, for whom the hunger striker Bobby Sands played as a boy. The accusation is academic since there is no copyright on a life story, but Lloyd Webber may be sensitive to it as he says he does not recall the precise programme that triggered his interest.

"I remember seeing a documentary about young children in northern Ireland," he says. "Apparently there were several documentaries and I can't remember which one it was. I thought if you have something like a team, it's a bit like the pub in EastEnders - you've got a forum in which things can happen. It's not really about football at all. It struck me that there was just possibly the germ of an idea there. I have a hundred ideas like this all the time; this happened to be the first one I mentioned to Ben and he happened to pick up on it."

The musical follows the lives of the teenage players and their girlfriends as they grow up during the Troubles. There is a murder, a riot and an on-stage kneecapping. Critically, much will hinge on whether the bleak storyline, Elton's jokes and Lloyd Webber's lush music cohere. The story of young love in a divided community echoes West Side Story, and such comparisons might not favour Lloyd Webber, but it is a serious attempt to write a musical of and for our times. "We tried not to trivialise it and went for a tougher ending," he says. "We were very keen not to go for a sentimental ending."

Lloyd Webber once said that he didn't mind people hating his music, but he did dislike those who questioned his integrity. It's a fair point. The art is a legitimate target - can complex politics be got across in a few anthemic songs? - but the intention is not. He has been criticised for latching on to the trendy subject of football, but, as he says, that is only a starting point for the show. In any case, he is no latecomer to the game, having supported Leyton Orient since he was a boy (his mother used to drop him off at the ground while she taught piano to impoverished pupils in east London).

Lloyd Webber has the look of a man who thinks he has a hit on his hands, but doesn't want to tempt fate by saying so. "It's going the same way as Cats went. The box office took off last week. It's one of those shows that might have a lousy first night for some reason, and it might not fly, but it has had a couple of preview nights when it has flown."

Lloyd Webber looks a great deal happier than he did in 1997 when troubles were coming, as ever, in battalions. Polygram had bought a majority stake in his company and was threatening to take full control, which would have meant him losing his lucrative copyrights. Sunset Boulevard had underperformed, hitting the Really Useful Group's profitability. Then, as the election loomed, he became a national laughing stock when he was reported (wrongly, he insists) as saying that he would leave the country if Labour won. Wags put much of the huge Labour majority down to his intervention.

The real crisis was the potential loss of the copyrights. "That would have taken control of the company away from me," he says. "We had to stop that somehow and due to various twists of fate we were terribly lucky and pulled off the impossible." The company is now entirely his again, though he says he is hands off.

"We have very good people here and if they want to do something I let them get on and do it. For example, they're developing a musical with the Pet Shop Boys at the moment. This is written up in the press as Lloyd Webber produces Pet Shop Boys, but of course it isn't. What we're thinking of doing, to allow the young people here some space, is having a wholly owned subsidiary with a different name, so that Really Useful doesn't produce anything other than mine. There are a couple of plays they've optioned, and that appears in the press as me doing it. But plays are not my forte."

Lloyd Webber is both composer and businessman: he writes musicals for a West End that is now largely owned by his company. The Really Useful Group's travails in the mid-90s made him realise that the days of the blockbuster were over. The Beautiful Game is accordingly less extravagant than some of its predecessors, a return to the relative simplicity of Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat. He thinks Sunset Boulevard, a perfectly good show in his view, was sunk by its extravagance. "There were places where it could never make money. It shouldn't have been done. You can't have a show that will only work if it's playing at 90% capacity." His rule of thumb now is that investors should recoup their money in under a year with a show running at 85% capacity.

Sorting out the politics has been almost as difficult as regaining control of the business. He denies that he threatened to leave the country if Labour were elected. What he actually said was that a high-tax regime would cause technicians to leave, and that in turn would make it hard for him to work here. He was ennobled by John Major and still takes the Conservative whip in the Lords, but he says he is a most reluctant Tory.

"I knew John Major and liked him a lot, but I'm not sure what I'm going to do in the future. I think that, despite the glitch that is happening at the moment, this government has done pretty well. I'm not a particular fan of the opposition. I voted with the government on section 28 because I felt very strongly that that was wrong; so I don't know that I am necessarily a natural conservative. I'm lucky in one sense that I'm not in the House of Lords as a working peer. I'm an honorary peer and I took the Tory whip because I knew that John Major must have had a huge hand in it. In my heart of hearts I know that I'm a cross-bencher."

He enjoys making occasional interventions in public affairs. He wrote to the Telegraph last week to suggest that the Dome be burned in a conflagration that would attract paying spectators (his old collaborator Tim Rice called him to say the letter was the best thing he had written since Evita). He also wrote a column for three years for the Telegraph - he gave it up to write The Beautiful Game - and says he misses it.

Perhaps he is loathed because, like Melvyn Bragg, he won't stay in his artistic box. He is composer, entrepreneur and public figure: bright, opinionated and uncompromising. He is also, of course, extremely rich, with a personal fortune of £420m, according to the Sunday Times Rich List. He and his third wife, Madeleine, own a stud; they have racehorses; he has the world's finest collection of pre-Raphaelite paintings; he once shelled out £18m for a Picasso.

Artists are supposed to be broke; he manifestly isn't. Artists are collected; he collects, with the obsessiveness of the small boy who adored trains. He is a curious and interesting figure: steeped in serious music yet in love with musical theatre; rich enough not to fret about politics but fretting anyway; oddly delighted to have won an award at the Newbury show last weekend for his organic peas; and anxious enough to run out into the street in the rain to give me the name of a horse of his that he thinks will win at Ascot tomorrow. Crystal Music. That's the horse, not a comment on the show, just in case my Lloyd Webber-loathing friend was worrying.

David Aidley, who has died aged 63, was a member of a small group of animal biologists and biophysicists who came together in the 1960s in the newly-founded University of East Anglia (UEA) with a brief to design and establish a school of biological sciences fully integrated in all its teaching, research and administrative activities.

When he arrived at UEA in 1967 as a lecturer, Aidley immediately saw, and supported throughout his career, the advantages of a "school" structure. While completing his book, The Physiology Of Excitable Cells, he realised the importance of a sound physico-chemical understanding, and was influenced by the discussions he had with colleagues in the school, and the ease with which such boundary crossing could occur. He entered into the early debates about the structure of the school and its courses with knowledge and enthusiasm. In discussion, he was wise, steady and reliable.

Aidley's academic background had been traditional. He attended Manchester grammar school from 1948 to 1955, leaving with a scholarship to Queens' College, Cambridge, where, and after two years of national service in the RAF, he read the natural sciences tripos, with zoology as his specialist subject, graduating in 1960. His postgraduate research in the general field of insect neuro-muscular physiology was supervised at Cambridge by JWS Pringle and AL Hodgkin. His first job was as a demonstrator in zoology at Oxford University in 1963, and he received his PhD a year later.

Aidley was an excellent teacher; his practical classes, based on the profligate use of plasticine, were a delight. The extent of his interests was amazing. In 1967, he joined the Amazon expedition of the Alpha Helix, a research vessel from the Scripps Institute, La Jolla, California. On that trip, he became interested in insect sound production and hearing. In 1973-74, he went to the International Centre of Insect Physiology in Nairobi, where he carried out research on the physiology and migratory behaviour of the African armyworm, a pest of grasses. He also developed his interests in ornithology and bird migration, and he and his wife, Jessica, did a lot of field work together.

This period in Nairobi triggered a deep interest in African biology, and he returned in 1980-82, first as a visiting researcher in ornithology, and latterly as visiting professor and head of department at Bayero University, in Kano, Nigeria.

Aidley's books are also a delight. He had a most unusual talent for explaining difficult scientific concepts. His style was graceful and his aim in identifying the crucial experimental evidence was unerring. His most notable achievement remains his first book on excitable cells, now in its fourth edition. He recently launched another specialist book (written with PR Stanfield) called Ion Channels: Molecules In Action, which was well reviewed and is proving popular. In between, Aidley wrote several reviews, an elementary text (with RD Keynes) on nerve and muscle, and edited a book on animal migration.

He was a keen bibliophile and, as chairman of the university library committee, devised a programme of budget cuts based on sound psephological principles, which he published in the British Journal of Academic Librarianship. He also wrote Analyse Your Diet, a computer programme for students to analyse their daily intake of nutrients and consider the implications, which sold well commercially.

Although he was still "living with questions", Aidley was a Christian, who believed that man's role on earth was to serve others, as he did, genially and diffidently.

His first marriage, to Patricia, ended in divorce. His marriage to Jessica in 1971 was a deeply happy partnership and they had four children: Richard, Timothy, Kate and Jack. They all survive him.

 David John Aidley, biologist, born February 5 1937; died August 24 2000

At least one Nato country is expected to dispatch troops to Sierra Leone to bolster the crumbling United Nations peacekeeping force following India's decision yesterday to withdraw its 3,000 soldiers and abandon command of the operation, according to western diplomatic sources.

The Indian pullout comes amid bitter infighting with the Nigerian contingent, and follows accusations of weak leadership and fears that the mission could collapse because of poor quality troops and equipment.

The UN security council has already agreed to increase the size of the largest peacekeeping operation in the world to 20,500 troops. With the withdrawal of the Indians, about 10,000 new soldiers now have to be found to serve in Sierra Leone.

The sources said that a sizeable number is likely to be drawn from one or more eastern European members of Nato and from Latin America, but that agreements with the governments concerned have to be finalised.

Britain has ruled out joining the UN force in Sierra Leone although it has more than 200 soldiers there to train the new army and to provide security.

The decision to bring in European and Latin American troops is a marked shift away from the UN security council's - and consequently the British and American - policy of encouraging regional peacekeeping forces in Africa.

It comes amid accusations that western nations are not prepared to risk the lives of white soldiers in Africa, and much hand wringing by world leaders at the millennium summit earlier this month over the dire state of peacekeeping on the continent.

Although the Indians say their withdrawal is routine and expected, it follows a stinging attack by the force's Indian commander, General Vijay Jetley, on the sizeable Nigerian contingent in Sierra Leone.

In a confidential report first made public in the Guardian, Gen Jetley accused Nigerian political and military officials at the top of the UN mission of "sabotaging peace" in favour of national interests, and alleged that Nigerian army commanders illegally mined diamonds in league with Revolutionary United Front rebels.

After the report was published, the Nigerian army called for Gen Jetley's immediate resignation and said it could no longer work with him. But the general's comments reflected considerable concern within the UN mission about the conduct and intent of the Nigerian army which has plundered Liberia and Sierra Leone during earlier military interventions.

The Indian withdrawal could be a blow to the British strategy in Sierra Leone of pushing the UN into confronting the RUF through a peace enforcement role while trying to keep the Nigerians from taking control. But it might also prove an opportunity if it can be used to persuade other European armies to join the peacekeeping force and provide the quality of troops and equipment now lacking.

The Jordanian contingent - whose troops were strongly criticised for fraternising with the West Side Boys who abducted 11 British soldiers last month - has added to the pressure for western involvement by saying that it too may pull out unless at least one Nato country sends troops.

Britain's minister for Africa, Peter Hain, who ruled out direct UK participation in the peacekeeping mission yesterday, said that the UN force would not be allowed to collapse.

"All options are being explored with member countries, including Nato countries, but Britain is very overstretched in Kosovo, with Iraq and in Northern Ireland," he said. "There will be a fully fledged UN peacekeeping operation in Sierra Leone. It will be a better force with an improved command structure."

The Sierra Leone army has occupied the village of Magbeni, one of two West Side Boys bases stormed by British troops earlier this month. The Sierra Leone military said its troops "encountered no resistance".

The troubled Manufacturing, Science and Finance union is being asked to impose an emergency £3m savings package to balance its books in the wake of a year of overspending and huge payouts to staff.

A confidential report from the union's accountants, HW Fisher, which was discussed by the union's finance and general purposes committee yesterday, calls for the union to impose £3m savings and introduce a virtual freeze on most activities until the end of this year.

One senior MSF officer told the Guardian: "We are facing a financial catastrophe". The accountants' report offers a series of unpalatable options to prevent the union going permanently into the red.

These include selling either the union's Dublin headquarters, housed in the former American embassy, or its residential training institution, Whitehall College at Bishop's Stortford in Hertfordshire, and imposing big cuts on staff by reducing the headcount from the present 375 to a maximum of 300.

Proposals discussed include scrapping an autumn campaign on health and safety issues in the workplace; wholesale cancellation of union publications until the end of the year; reducing union training courses at the college, including new ones on equal opportunities for women and ethnic minorities; banning officials from travelling to meet one another on union business; and cancelling meetings of sector committees to discuss industry issues.

The cuts arrive as Roger Lyons, the union's general secretary, has come under fire for alleged lavish expense claims, and for losing and then having to settle a series of employment tribunal cases, which have cost members £900,000.

Allegations were made by one "whistleblower", Marcia Solomon, who won a £50,000 settlement for unfair dismissal, that Mr Lyons and Nelson Mendes, head of the finance department, fiddled thousands of pounds in expenses.

Mr Mendes is on sick leave, and according to a national executive report is not likely to work for the union again.

The union has instructed lawyers to fight an unfair dismissal case being brought by Bryan Keegan, former chauffeur to the general secretary, which is due to be heard in January.

Lawyers are also being asked to take action to close down a website run by MSF member David Beaumont, which details Mr Lyons' alleged expense claims, lists articles in the press on the lifestyle of the general secretary, and reports on tribunal cases.

The union is having to pay back £600,000 a year to the banks to cut its overdraft and needs to put aside £750,000 fully to fund its pension scheme. Earlier this year the union's pension trustees in their report indicated "dismay and anger" over Mr Lyons' failing to consult them on a £200,000 payout to three senior union staff who took early retirement.

Minutes of MSF's finance committee and national executive for the last four months - obtained by the Guardian - revealed a steadily deteriorating financial situation as the union lost a series of tribunal cases.

Last year the union was running a £182,000 surplus each month. By last April the surplus had dwindled to £4,000 a month, falling to £2,200 a month in May.

The national executive was told in June by HW Fisher that to remain viable "on an income of £26m, the union should be generating a 'basic' surplus of £1m per annum as a minimum level for an efficient organisation."

The report added the union could not continue to pay £600,000 off its overdraft by selling property, and that pension contributions would have to increase from 6% to 19% to protect the scheme.

The July finance committee was told that savings of £2m were urgently required - but the committee told the accountants these savings were now not enough and ordered them back for a rethink.

Other changes being implemented include new expenses forms, which for the first time require NEC members and the general secretary to obtain counter-signatures.

Paul Talbot, secretary to the finance committee, said last night: "These recommendations from the accountants are good housekeeping measures. Our aim is to bring more management control into the union without stopping our frontline activities.It is part of ongoing discussion on how we run our finances over the next three years."

The union insisted that its finances were stable.

Like the old grandfather clock in the corner, the US presidential election swings back and forth. At first, the Republican George W Bush had a dominant lead. But when he faced a more daunting challenge than the Democrats' Al Gore did in his primary for the party nomination, the latter took the lead.

Then, it was Vice-President Gore who stumbled and went strangely quiet in the post-primary period; Mr Bush regained the advantage.

At the Republican convention in early August, Mr Bush took a decisive lead, only to hand it back when the Democrats met later that month. The seminal event of the campaign, so far, has been Mr Gore's magnificent convention speech accepting his party's nomination.

Auditioning for the presidency, Mr Gore delivered a speech devoid of oratorical flourish but so laden with substance that it resembled a president's annual state of the union address.

Mr Gore took America on a tour of his agenda. He proposed important initiatives in areas from education to child care to help for the el derly to health reform to crime fighting to environmental protection and, in the process, touched on a dozen other popular themes.

Now, one month later, the echoes of Mr Gore's speech still sound in the race, staking the vice-president to a small but so far enduring lead over Mr Bush.

For his part, Mr Bush has countered by "triangulating". This was the strategy Bill Clinton used in 1996 to steal the other side's issues. With all the basic Republican concerns basically solved - such as eliminating the deficit (the US has a surplus), cutting crime (down 50%), and reducing dependence on the dole (also cut in half) - Mr Bush has crossed into Democratic turf to find his issues.

His convention emphasised his commitment to education and he recently unveiled a plan to pay for medicine for the elderly. The logic of the Bush strategy is that if he can draw even with Mr Gore on the issues, he will win on image - the calculation being that barring a transplant of DNA, Mr Gore cannot win the personality battle.

The flaw in the Republican approach, so far, is Mr Bush's huge proposed tax cut. Seeking to reduce tax payments by $1,300bn (£865bn) in the next 10 years, the nominee is betting his house that voters want their taxes cut first and foremost. But most surveys show they are far more apt to favour spending on education, gun control, police, and help to impoverished areas.

Either side can win this contest. But it is worth noting that not since 1948 has the candidate who is behind at this stage come back to win the election.

Richard Nixon in 1960, Hubert Humphrey in 1968, and Gerald Ford in 1976 all came close, but none won. Bad news for Mr Bush.

Dick Morris, chief strategist for President Clinton in his successful 1996 bid for re-election, will be writing a regular column during the US election campaign. He is head of www.vote.co.uk an interactive website designed to give users a voice on public issues

Rivers and canals in England and Wales are probably cleaner than they have been since the industrial revolution, with 92% classed as good enough to support fish life, according to the Environment Agency.

This 1999 figure is a big improvement on 1990, the year after water privatisation, when 85% of the 25,000 miles of rivers and canals were classified in the top two categories of "good" or "fair".

If Scotland and Northern Ireland are included the figure is 95% in 1999, compared with 92% in 1990.

Since privatisation, water companies have been forced by EU legislation to invest heavily in sewage treatment plants and other clean-up measures which have resulted in higher water bills but better water quality. Hundreds of miles of rivers now have fish life where there was none nine years ago.

Rivers in the "poor" and "bad" classifications have probably been devoid of almost all life for decades, many of them in the old industrial heartlands of Britain, where chemicals used to be indiscriminately poured into the nearest stream.

In 1990, 2.3% of all rivers were still in the "bad" category - meaning about 575 miles of rivers had no life - but last year this figure had gone down to 0.6%, around 150 miles.

The biggest improvements have been in industrial areas of the midlands and northern England, where around half the rivers and canals have improved by one grade or more. The net improvement, taking into account the fact that some rivers have deteriorated over the same period, is equivalent to upgrading 40% of the total river and canal length in the midlands and north.

The quality of rivers is one of the government's 15 indicators of "quality of life" in Britain, which it pledged to improve. Water companies are due to spend another £7bn over the next five years making further improvements.

The environment minister, Michael Meacher, said: "Clean rivers are not only a vital source of water for drinking and industry, they also support a wide variety of wildlife and are enjoyed by millions for recreation.

"The billions being invested in cleaning up our rivers are really bearing fruit. These are the best ever water quality results, and they reflect the government's commitment to delivering a cleaner, better quality environment for everyone to enjoy."

The south west of England and Wales have the highest proportion of high quality rivers, with respectively 97% and 98% of river and canal length classified as good or fair.

The Environment Agency chairman, Sir John Harman, said: "The survey shows real improvements in the quality of many urban and semi-urban rivers, creating real amenity for people in areas where river environments have in the past been poor, or in some cases, lifeless, polluted eyesores.

"However, we cannot be complacent. Around 8% of rivers in England and Wales are still graded poor or bad. Planned investment over the next five years should tackle many of these problems."

 The agency has a website, www.environment-agency.gov.uk, where users can enter a postcode to discover the quality of rivers in their given locality.

Burma's ruling junta blocked pro-democracy leader Aung San Suu Kyi from leaving the capital, Rangoon, by train yesterday by confining her to a station waiting room and refusing to let her and members of the National League for Democracy (NLD) buy tickets.

Ms Suu Kyi, who was kept under house arrest for two weeks earlier this month after being prevented from travelling to rural areas by car, and nine party colleagues were told that all the tickets to Mandalay had been sold.

This was blatantly not true as several of the trains that left for Burma's second city, 375 miles to the north of Rangoon, were far from full.

Ms Suu Kyi, who was travelling to Mandalay to check reports that NLD activities there were being restricted by the military regime, was still at the station well after the last train left at 9pm.

There was no word on whether she was planning to stay at the station and further test the restrictions on her movement or return home.

Security at the station was extremely heavy with truckloads of riot police and scores of plainclothes officers swarming all over the area.

A few dozen NLD supporters who turned up in advance to demonstrate were whisked away while journalists and British diplomats were refused entry.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, said yesterday that it was clear that Burma's generals were not sincere in their desire to further democracy because "they continually harass those who exercise their democratic rights".

Earlier in the day police vans and cars sealed off the road outside Ms Suu Kyi's house. It is not clear whether the authorities let her through or whether she managed to evade the blockade.

The last time Ms Suu Kyi, 55, who won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1991, tried to go to Mandalay by train was in 1996. Then the authorities uncoupled her carriage just before the train was due to leave, citing technical problems.

Yesterday's bid to travel signalled Ms Suu Kyi's latest clash of wills with the ruling generals who refuse to recognise the NLD's landslide victory in the 1990 general election.

The military regularly restricts her movement and imprisons party colleagues. She was kept under house arrest from 1989 to 1995

Last month's crackdown on Ms Suu Kyi and the NLD provoked international condemnation, particularly from Britain and the United States.

Earlier this week Burma's foreign minister, Win Aung, said at the UN general assembly in New York that the impoverished country was not yet ready for full democracy and such criticism hindered the transition process.

An advert was run recently in the print Guardian for Solar Century, the UK solar power company devised and presided over by former Greenpeace representative and Oxford fellow Jeremy Leggett. The advert incites us to consider what may happen when supplies of carbon fuel begin to run out, what sort of blockades and panics we will suffer, what sort of squabbles at the pump. Now, the advert suggests, before it is too late, for oil supplies, and for the future of the planet, we should turn to solar alternatives.

Solar Century is an unabashedly commercial enterprise. Its website offers a range of solar products, from roof installations of various sizes to portable powermats. The aim of the company is to hurry the conversion to solar power in Britain, for fiscal profit. However, Solar Century also runs a charitable trust, aiming to extend solar power to those less likely to be able to afford the conversion rates, the Solar Century Global Community Trust.

What companies such as Solar Century are aiming to demonstrate is the economic viability of solar photovoltaic (PV) power. As usual, Britain is lagging behind countries such as Japan and Germany, where government schemes have propelled rates of conversion. We remain at the level of unconverted barbarism: the Solar Century site aims to correct a few of our more primitive preconceptions. Will it work in the dark? Will it work in the clouds? The answer to both questions is, of course, yes.

At the present time, most solar roofs are connected to the national grid. So, in the day when a surplus of electricity is generated, the excess is effectively sold to the local electricity company. At night, the local electricity network supplies the power back. Clouds interfere only slightly with the workings of solar panels. Electricity is created by daylight - cloud cover may diminish the output, but there will still be power.

Solar Century orchestrate discussions with the local electricity companies, who are compelled by law to let customers install solar power anyway and to buy surplus electricity created by the panels. Planning permission is rarely required, unless the solar roof has been designed to project wildly beyond the frame of the house.

Faced with these sorts of enterprises, it seems absurd that we do not, as a nation, convert instantly. Global warming, caused by carbon emissions throughout the world, but particularly in developed, industrialized countries, is no longer even a debatable probability. Its effects have already been witnessed - freak weather conditions, floods in China, El Nino storms buffeting the Atlantic coast.

This summer the northern polar ice cap melted. Scientists respected for their rigour and precision are predicting monstrous, apocalyptic future effects, including a sea level rise of one metre, which will destroy the homes and livelihoods of, for example, 30m people living in Bangladesh, Egypt and Vietnam.

The first recommendations from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) in 1990 were for a 60% reduction in carbon dioxide emissions, as the basic level required to return the planet's climate to a healthy level. Governments globally have failed to commit to anything even approaching this.

Various dubious enterprises have been created to allow further evasion of carbon cuts for richer countries, including the carbon credits scheme, which creates a trade in carbon emission entitlements - a company which emits below its allowed level will be able to sell its surplus allowance to another.

This once more means that money will save individuals, companies and nations from significantly altering their lifestyles. It was George Bush senior, as US president in the early days of international climate panels and conferences in the 1980s, who suavely assured the world that the American lifestyle was not negotiable.

Now America has seen some of the worst, most destructive storms in its history: Florida devastated, Texas drought-riddled, heatwaves sweeping the midwest and the south, killing the young and the elderly. And now this year and last, an encephalitis epidemic in New York City.

In the UK, we are more fortunate. So far, we have evaded some of the more sinister and appalling demonstrations of climate change. But we are inactive, clinging to our petrol and our cars, clinging to the core comforts of life, "core comforts" we have known for less than a century. There is one area in which we might act. We might, given that it is so extraordinarily easy, convert our homes to solar power.

The use of renewable energies no longer requires individuals to adopt eccentric living patterns, to retire to the Lake District and hammer up a windmill on the top of the fell. Solar power is there for the installing, by competent, mainstream, commercially minded Oxford fellows and their team (which includes figures no less mainstream and commercial than former employees of BP).

We scarcely have to do anything. We are not required to leave our homes, we are not required to picket or protest, to storm and rave. We are merely required to adjust our thinking slightly. To adapt.

When I am called upon to write about the mostly fictional entity called Spinal Tap, I usually do so in the mostly fictional character of David St Hubbins, long-time guitarist/clothes-horse for said group. David can knock the piece off at one sitting, email it to his manager, and be back in bed by 10am. But the one thing David St Hubbins can't do for us is talk about a movie called This Is Spinal Tap. None of the band can give you a rundown on the odd genesis of this film, because it doesn't exist in their world. So I'm filling in.

In 1978, Rob Reiner, fresh from a long distinguished stretch in series television, put together a special called The TV Show. It spooved (yes, that is the correct word) network and local television, satirising a full viewing day's worth of crap in one hour. It was very funny.

I knew Rob, and several of the writers were old friends of mine. One of the proposed pieces was a parody of a show called Midnight Special, a rock'n'roll concert/variety show, hosted by the late Wolfman Jack. Christopher Guest, who would go on to play the Tap's Nigel Tufnel, suggested that a pea-brained English rock band be featured in the sketch. Chris and I had played a couple of road-weary Britrockers in a short piece he had directed so I became involved in the project. Chris, Rob, the show's producer Harry Shearer (who would play Tap bassist Derek Smalls) and I wrote the song Rock'n'Roll Nightmare and its accompanying visual foolishness. After some groping about for a suitably duff name, we settled on Spinal Tap.

About a year and a half later, Rob was looking to direct feature films, and the notion of doing a fake documentary about this awful band snowballed. Rob pitched the idea and got a hearty "maybe" from Sir Lew Grade's US wing, Marble Arch. In early 1980, the four of us began meeting daily to furnish Spinal Tap with a believable past. We watched a lot of rock'n'roll concert and documentary film, and noted the recurrence of an interesting theme: the survivor - the yeoman road warrior who never says die, no matter how clearly the market suggests he do so.

We had no intention of writing a screenplay. The idea was to construct the history of the band and the characters, set the general story elements and improvise the dialogue, having hired actors we knew could play the game. We shot a demo in four days and Rob assembled the piece over the next few months. In the interim, Marble Arch had released Legend of the Lone Ranger and Raise the Titanic (right boat, wrong direction!) in rapid succession and slipped quietly out of the Big Tent.

We assumed it was not going to happen. We all went back to our day gigs and night sweats until Lindsay Doran, a fan of Rob's and a bright light at Embassy Pictures, suggested they just make the damn thing anyway. Jerry Parenchio and Norman Lear, dean of Reiner's alma mater, All in the Family, were running Embassy, and things fell gradually into place. We began writing, casting and crewing in the spring of 1982.

Peter Smokler's camera rolled late in that year. We had cast old buds like Paul Benedict, Billy Crystal, Ed Begley and Paul Shaffer, along with new friends Fran Drescher, Dana Carvey, Patrick Macnee, Anjelica Huston, et al. Ric Parnell and David Kaff came aboard as drummer Mick Shrimpton and keyboardist Viv Savage. June Chadwick was cast as Jeanine, St Hubbins's ladylove. Tony Hendra became our manager, the faithless Ian Faith. We asked everyone to come and improvise with us. We'd made very few miscalculations: the actors got the joke and flew with it, and every day's shooting was at least as much fun as the day before. Rob edited the film over the next year, and the film was released in March of 1984.

The critics liked us very much. The public that found us, either by fluke or in response to the "trickledown" theory of promotion, found us funny. But we were a modestly budgeted satirical film with a very specific voice; we gave the bigger spring releases no serious nightmares. It did play in one theatre in Boston for something like a year, and the fans we encountered were smart and funny and flattering. This Is Spinal Tap made a lot of Best of the Year lists; it just didn't crack 1984's top 10 box office. But it was the movie we had wanted to make, and we were very happy with it.

Video release widened our circle of friends; bits of Tapspeak found their way into the language. We had achieved an important goal: shelf-life, the ability to stay fresh and crisp while other comedy gets stale and mouldy. When someone reports watching the movie regularly and finding new stuff to laugh at each time, it makes us very glad. Lots of other stuff has happened since. Rob, Harry, Chris and I have been thankfully busy most of the time - but for each of us the making of this strange movie was a high point.

Michael McKean

Authenticity

The band wrote and performed all the music from the film, with collaboration from Rob Reiner. Harry Shearer has spoken of the irony that many real bands rely on miming to pre-recorded tracks for their live performances, while "the joke band really plays". Christopher Guest concludes: "What we've seen over the years, when we've played live, is that people want to feel as if they're part of the movie. Because they were the audience watching this movie, the audience that comes to the show feel as if they are now in the movie in a funny way, and they become the audience in the movie and it's very difficult to separate. It's a very bizarre phenomenon. They know all the songs and we can never tell... are they joking? Or do they know?... At what point does this become real or imagined?"

Backstage requirements

In This Is Spinal Tap, Nigel Tufnel is seen being appeased by the band's manager, Ian Faith, as he runs through what is wrong with the backstage catering. The particular inspirations were the peculiar demands made by Jerry Lewis, Yul Brynner and especially Van Halen - who, according to legend, insist on being served bowls of M&Ms with the brown ones taken out. Michael McKean recalls Brynner's contract for backstage provisions demanding: "Under no circumstances must white eggs be substituted for brown."

Guest recalls of Spinal Tap's real tours: "We also suffered many of the ignominies that the band did in the film. Art imitating life that had already imitated art. At one gig there was half a sandwich and a pitcher of water in the dressing room. That was it. At least the sandwich was wrapped in plastic"

Bizarre gardening accident

The manner of original Tap drummer John "Stumpy" Pepys's death in 1969. The idea of the "bizarre gardening accident" has entered the language and the popular imagination. Angry Salad, a Boston-based rock band, have released an album by that name and it is rumoured that Jeff Porcaro, the drummer of Toto, may in fact have died in this way in 1992, eight years after the release of This Is Spinal Tap. One theory has it that Porcaro was spraying insecticide in his garden and inhaled too much, triggering a fatal heart attack. Ironically, Toto's lead guitarist, Steve Lukather, served as producer and guitarist on Spinal Tap's Break Like the Wind in the same year.

Cher

Cher was one of the celebrity collaborators on the Tap's comeback project, Break Like the Wind. She sang with St Hubbins on Just Begin Again. The collaboration was hampered by Cher's apparent animosity towards her co-singer - as St Hubbins recalled in a 1992 interview in The Nose: "It was great in one sense that she insisted on me not being anywhere near her when she sings. In fact, the papers said I had to be 100 yards away from Cher when she's actually doing vocals, which would be a house-and-a-half down the road from the studio where we were doing it." When asked why Cher didn't join the band in person for their comeback tour, St Hubbins explained: "We begged, we pleaded, and finally she agreed not to."

Don't Look Back

DA Pennebaker's seminal rockumentary of Bob Dylan's UK tour of 1965. One of the declared inspirations for This Is Spinal Tap, the film offers a searingly candid view of the young, supremely confident Dylan on tour. We see him granting an audience to his nervous acolyte Donovan who sings To Sing For You in a nearly embarrassing homage to his idol. Dylan is shown suffering from the everyday niggles of touring, such as singing The Times They Are A-Changin' with an initially dysfunctional mike - it isn't plugged in. The most obvious reference in This Is Spinal Tap is the getting-lost-backstage scene. After the Manchester gig, Dylan and his entourage are seen scurrying around backstage desperately trying to find their way out, and Dylan enquires urgently: "Where's the door?"

Eleven

In one of the great sequences of modern film comedy, Nigel, having shown Marty DiBergi (Rob Reiner) his beloved guitar collection, introduces him to his Marshall amp: "This is a top to what we use on stage, but it's very, very special because, if you can see, the numbers all go to 11. Look, right across the board: 11, 11, 11."

Marty: "And most amps go up to 10."

Nigel: "Exactly."

Marty: "Does that mean it's louder? Is it any louder?"

Nigel: "Well, it's one louder, isn't it?"

This exchange has become so embedded in the mythology of rock that the number 11 now has a separate and instantly accessible meaning. Eddie Van Halen is reputed to be the first rock guitarist to have been inspired by Spinal Tap and request a customised amp with dials going up to 11.

Christopher Guest speaks in his commentary for the special laser disc edition of the film of how he has worked with the hi-fi company since the time of the film's production: "Marshall made a special plate for me that went up to 11. Subsequently they have done some ads with me, and now the new amp that they made for me actually goes up to infinity on the dial. They made a real amp that goes up to 20. That's the one that people can buy in the stores now for real. But mine goes up to infinity. This has been ripped off big time. Almost every amp company now sells knobs that go up to 11."

Foghat

British boogie-blues band formed in 1970 who became successful in the US in the mid-70s. McKean, Shearer and Guest insist that the events in the film are not based on specific bands or personalities, but acts continue to claim or protest that they are the models. As Michael McKean explained in an interview with the Guardian: "We were accused by someone from Foghat of planting a bug in their bus because they swore that we had ripped off the idea of the girlfriend taking over and using astrology to plan the tour."

Fufkin, Artie

Promoter at Polymer Records, Tap's label. In the NME on September 8 1984, Harry Shearer spoke of how people in the record industry would identify with the spoof: "A lot of people from record companies bug us now. They take you aside and say, 'Well, Harry, if I say it myself, I'm the Artie Fufkin of this burgh,' not realising it's sort of a damning indictment."

Guest, Christopher

Plays Nigel Tufnel. Son of Lord Peter Haden-Guest and Jean Hindes, aka Lady Jean Haden-Guest, former vice-president of CBS. In 1984, the year This Is Spinal Tap was released, Guest married the actress Jamie Lee Curtis at Rob Reiner's home. Reputedly, Lee Curtis was first attracted to Guest when she saw his picture in Rolling Stone magazine, and arranged a date with him through his agent. In 1996, after the death of his father, Guest was ennobled as the fifth Baron Haden-Guest of Saling. In the Register of Lords' Interests, Guest is declared offly as: "Film director." He is the half-brother of journalist and bon vivant Anthony Haden-Guest, who is widely believed to be the model for Peter Fallow, the louche, hard-drinking English journalist in Tom Wolfe's Bonfire of the Vanities.

Huston, Angelica

Plays the designer of the Stonehenge set, Polly Deutsch. Huston emerged from the shadows after Spinal Tap, starring in Prizzi's Honor (1985), The Dead (1987), Crimes and Misdemeanours (1989), The Grifters (1990) and The Addams Family (1991).

Iron Butterfly

One of the first heavy rock bands, Iron Butterfly were formed in San Diego in 1966. It is fitting that there should be strong links between the Tap and Iron Butterfly, for whom the description "heavy metal" is believed to have been coined. The band plotted a similar course to the Tap, moving from psychedelia to heavy rock and pushing the envelope of the four-minute pop song to the epic form with their classic In-A-Gadda-Da-Vida (the album of the same name is said to have sold 25m copies). Spinal Tap played their first live gig at Gazzari's on Sunset Strip, in a double bill with Iron Butterfly.

Judas Priest

One of the bands to which the Tap have consistently been likened. As part of his research for This Is Spinal Tap, Rob Reiner went to see Judas Priest: "It physically hurt my chest. The reverberation in the hall was so strong that I couldn't stay there any longer."

Kunkel, Russ

The famed session drummer who appeared as the drummer in the band's first appearance on The TV Show and played Eric "Stumpy" Joe in the band's jamboreebop appearance. Kunkel has served as producer for Clannad and played with Emmylou Harris, BB King and Bob Seger.

Last Waltz, The

Directed by Martin Scorsese, one of the inspirations for Martin DiBergi, this proto-rockumentary records the last performance by The Band, which Robbie Robertson describes as "the beginning of the end of the beginning".

The interview technique of This Is Spinal Tap is lifted straight from The Last Waltz, where Scorsese placed himself in front of the camera for some of his chats with the band, of which he was a declared fan. In the interviews, the band explain that they got together having been assured that they would get "more pussy than Frank Sinatra".

Among the film's Tap-like moments: the band members discuss the pleasures and pains of 16 years on the road, and the tensions and joys created by mixing music and women; a very obviously and chronically goofed keyboardist, Richard Manuel, recalls the band's problems with settling on a name: "It was right in the middle of the whole psychedelia, Chocolate Strawberries and Marshmallow Overcoat - those kind of names. They were the Hawks and toyed with becoming the Crackers or the Honkies before eventually settling on the Band." In a very Tap-like observation, Robbie Robertson acknowledges what rock'n'roll had done for them: "It took us everywhere. It took us to some strange places... physically, spiritually and psychotically."

McKean, Michael

Actor playing David St Hubbins. Besides his moment of glory as St Hubbins, McKean has made a name for himself, like Shearer, as a voice artist, and in supporting corporate/nerdy roles, often faintly sinister.

Nash, Graham (1942-)

Rock star, born in Manchester, who was a founder member of the Hollies before forming Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young in 1967. He appears in The Return of Spinal Tap as the man who goes into Jeanine's shop, The Drippery, complaining of trouble with his chakra ball.

The Otto Show

The episode of The Simpsons, for which Shearer is a regular voice artist, in which Bart goes to his first heavy metal concert when Spinal Tap play Springfield. Marge is heard saying optimistically: "I hope the Spinal Tap don't play too loud." We see that Bart is wearing a T-shirt bearing the words: "Spinal Tap World Tour: London Paris Munich Springfield."

Pettibone, Jeanine

The presence of David St Hubbins's girl friend Jeanine in This Is Spinal Tap supplies what McKean, Guest and Shearer call "The Yoko plot". She represents the threat posed to the central duo by the appearance of a woman. Nigel and David are the core of the band, with obvious reference to Jagger/Richard, Lennon/McCartney and Page/Plant. Women are meant to be entertainment on tour and steady girlfriends or wives are anathema to the whole experience.

In Rotten: No Irish, No Blacks, No Do, John Lydon writes of his experiences in the Sex Pistols with his mate Sid Vicious and Sid's girlfriend, Nancy Spungen. After the break-up of the band, Rotten wanted to work again with Sid, who assured him he had given up drugs: "I told him to meet me at Gunter Grove so we could talk - provided he didn't bring Nancy, which he did. Nancy was getting at Sid and wanted to be his manager. The ego games were so appalling, it resembled something out of that rock'n'roll satire movie, Spinal Tap."

Pischedda, Tommy

Chauffeur played by Bruno Kirby. The special resentment between chauffeurs and rock stars reached its crisis point in 1976 when The Who's Keith Moon accidentally ran over and killed his own chauffeur, Cornelius Boland.

Plastercaster

Legendary rock chick Nancy Godfrey was famed for her collection of plastercasts of rock stars' dicks. Apparently Jimi Hendrix is the star exhibit. In a sequence featured in the original script for This Is Spinal Tap, Derek and Viv are seen in their Memphis hotel room with their bums immersed in plaster as a favour to two groupies who collect casts of rock stars' bottoms. The groupies strip the plaster off Derek and Viv - but too soon. The casts are shapeless messes.

Q

There is no Q.

Rock and Roll Creation

This Tap track entered musical legend because of the trouble Derek Smalls had emerging from his pod during the performance of the song, as captured on This Is Spinal Tap. The original idea for the band to be born on stage out of pods was borrowed from 70s heavy-rock band Angel.

For U2's Popmart tour, the show's designer Willie Williams and the band decided the group should emerge from a giant lemon. Asked what inspired the idea, Williams replied: "Spinal Tap, actually. We needed a pod-like object for the band to come out of like they did in the movie. We felt that the more smoke there was the better, because it was the pure Spinal Tap moment. Just then Las Vegas decided to have the stillest wind ever. So The Edge comes down from the stairs, and to start his guitar he has to kick a switch on his foot-pedal. Well, he ended up on his hands and knees, feeling around for the pedal. Later he said to me, 'There I was at the debut, the premiere opening night, and this voice came into my head: I'm Derek Smalls.'"

Stonehenge

It has been widely claimed that Spinal Tap's Stonehenge set was taken from a notorious Black Sabbath live extravaganza, the 1984 Born Again tour. In BBC TV's Rock Family Trees, Sabbath Bloody Sabbath, Ian Gillan (the then vocalist) recalls the meeting with LSD, the designers: "We were all going, 'Something earthy, maybe.' And Geezer said, 'Stonehenge.' The bloke says, 'That's a brilliant idea. How do you visualise it?' He said, 'Life-size of course.'"

The result was actually three times bigger than Stonehenge. Sabbath had to hire the Birmingham NEC for rehearsals as that was the only place it would fit - and that was without the stage. They assumed it would be all right in America, as "all the places are bigger over there". Then at the first gig they couldn't get it in the doors.

In the December 1994 issue of Mojo magazine, Gillan adds: "On the last day of rehearsal we're wondering what this dwarf is doing hanging around backstage. When we do the dress rehearsal, the dwarf emerges in a red leotard, long yellow fingernails and little yellow horns. He's going to be the baby [a diabolical baby is featured on the cover of the Born Again album]. Then we hear this horrendous [recorded] scream and suddenly we see this dwarf crawling across the top of Stonehenge. He stands up as the scream fades away and falls backwards off this 30ft fibreglass Stonehenge on to a pile of mattresses. Then - dong, dong - bells start tolling and all the roadies come across the front of the stage in monks' cowls, at which point War Pigs starts up."

At first this may seem like a case of the film being inspired by real incidents, but this is improbable - the tour happened the same year This Is Spinal Tap was released.

Troggs tapes

The British pop band, led by millionaire crop-circle enthusiast Reg Presley and famous for Wild Thing and Love Is All Around, became the subject of cult fame with the Troggs Tapes. These recordings, available on bootleg, were made during a session and display, according to The Penguin Encyclopaedia of Popular Music, "instrumental incompetence, mutual recrimination and much foul language". They inspired the sequence in which Tufnel and St Hubbins have their row in the Rainbow Trout Recording Studio.

Uriah Heep

One of key bands who inspired the Tap, the long-lived and resolutely unfashionable Heep enjoyed commercial success, especially in America, for three decades, and plodded on despite critical indifference or scorn, enduring more than 30 changes in personnel (particularly with drummers) and two deaths.

John Sinclair, the original keyboardist with Spinal Tap, had to leave the band when negotiations for the film were taking too long. He toured with Uriah Heep. When he returned to the project to contribute to the album, he told the band how Uriah Heep were once booked to play an air force base. Tap in turn play an air force base, where their sound system picks up military radio messages.

Vomit

Eric "Stumpy Joe" Childs, the Tap's second drummer, died in 1974 by choking on vomit, although it has never emerged whose vomit it was. AC/DC's lead singer Bon Scott died this way, as did Jimi Hendrix and Mama Cass Elliot, of The Mamas and the Papas. But the immediate inspiration for Stumpy Joe's death is John Bonham, drummer of Led Zeppelin. On the afternoon of September 24 1980, Bonham started a drinking binge that continued until midnight. The following afternoon an assistant went to rouse him and found him dead. He had consumed around 40 shots of vodka, suffered alcohol poisoning and choked on his vomit in his sleep.

Wainwright III, Loudon

In early incarnations of the Tap, singer-songwriter Loudon Wainwright III appeared as keyboard player.

Xanadu Star Theatre

The venue in Cleveland, Ohio where the band get lost backstage. In his commentary for the Criterion laser disc edition, Christopher Guest recalls the inspiration for the scene: "We saw a tape of Tom Petty playing somewhere in Germany, where he's walking backstage and a door's opened and he ends up on an indoor tennis court and there's just this moment of stunned, you know, 'Where am I?'"

Yes

Steven Soderbergh made a documentary of British prog-rock band Yes in the mid-80s called 9012 Live. In an interview with Soderbergh, Observer journalist Andrew Anthony asked incredulously if the film was made after This Is Spinal Tap. Soderbergh replied: "Yeah. I took Jon Anderson to see it and he came back and told the rest of the guys about it. They started watching it, like, every day because it was so their world."

Zappa, Dweezil

Son of rock guitarist Frank, who contributed a solo to Diva Fever on Break Like the Wind.
